She joins with yet another 'group' to try and escape.Whilst the visuals and some set pieces are still nicely done, Anderson appears to have run out of ideas and brings back creatures and characters from the earlier films and dumps any rules of engagement that the franchise once had straight in the bin. The result is a long, messy and illogical crash bang wallop fest for 95 minutes, culminating in an overlong and tedious anti climactic fight sequence on the ice.This film never gets exciting or witty or moving it's just a lot of explosions, guns and zombies. If that's what floats your boat, enjoy, but for most it's one long yawnfest.

Review title: Don't waste much time on this
Review_body: Resident Evil: Retribution is directed by Paul W.S. Anderson and stars Milla Jovovich, Sienna Guillory, Michelle Rodriguez, Aryana Engineer, Li Bingbing, Johann Urb, Boris Kodjoe and Kevin Durand in the leads.The movie is ridiculous and disappointing in many ways and the main disappointment is the cast which is probably the most weakest part of the movie. The movie is undoubtedly spot on for their action scenes and will be a treat for an eyes for the action lovers but apart from action the movie disappoints in a big way.Apart from Milla it seems that rest of the characters are forced to play the part and seems disinterested. The biggest blot was Michelle Rodriguez who did the acting with a blank face.Screenplay of the movie was tight and engaging, background music supports the screenplay beautifully.With pale star cast and their fade acting the movie is certainly a disappointment.

I've been a big fan of the very first "Resident Evil" movie because it had a unique horror film atmosphere, a twisted story and many intriguing characters. When I saw the second film, I was completely disappointed because it only focused on action scenes and had a very depressing and dumb atmosphere all the time. I disliked the film so much that I stopped caring for the sequels. In addition to this, the fascination of the initial concept has just worn out after numerous comics, novels, video games and movies. I feel that only the closed minded die hard fans will continue buying all this stuff and ignoring the lack of quality that has been replaced by an elevated quantity. As it seems, there are still enough of this people around to carry the whole concept on.I only watched this movie by pure coincidence as I passed a weekend with a friend who is a fan of the series and who asked me to go to watch this flick at his cheap local movie theatre with him. This new flick didn't inspire me at all to watch the flicks I've had missed or to continue following the series. It just underlines what I've already expected. The movie is filled with numerous action scenes, cheap effects and ultimately leads to another sequel while the characters have no development and while there is also a complete absence of any story whatsoever.There are still a few good points about this film. First of all, the location of a complex Soviet bunker system somewhere underneath the permafrost of North-East Russia is quite promising and definitely has its charm even if the idea had been used before. The decorations are overall quite stylish and a few shots are in fact very well done. Apart of this, I also enjoyed the simulated places the characters cross in this movie such as Tokyo, New York City or Moscow. These scenes are especially intriguing for people who adore to travel and discover the world as I do and at some moments, there are certain deja-vu effects. As a last point, I might say that I liked the addition of Li Bingbing to the movie. I have seen several Chinese flicks with her before she rose to fame and she definitely is a promising actress. It's sad that she is not acting very much in here in fact just like all the other characters that have no development. She's just there all of a sudden, incarnates a tough woman and shows us her long beautiful legs. That's definitely nice to watch but she has clearly more than just this to offer and the team wasted a lot of promising potential.In the end, this movie seems to be another continuous step down for the Resident Evil universe. There will be more movies but I hope it will stop anytime soon. While the makers of the comparable Underworld saga were able to pull of a quite decent new flick this year, the team behind Resident Evil fails while it tries. Let's hope for an explosive final chapter before the whole thing will finally be brought to an end. I can only recommend this movie to the die hard fans, anyone else should skip this, watch the first and best feature again and discover more movies with Li Bingbing.

Review title: I'm a fan of the franchise...
Review_body: The Resident Evil franchise is very successful and relevant for a reason, it has a loyal fan-base and the movies are made in a way that avid gamers who play the video game version of the films can see and appreciate that the films were made with them (the players who have made the game popular) in mind. If you are not one of the people described in the previous sentence, then it's quite possible that you will have qualms with project Alice and the RE saga. I am a fan of both the video games and the film series so I did not have any problems with this edition, in fact I loved the idea of them bringing back villains and scorned characters from the previous series of films for Alice to face-off with. Leon S Kennedy has finally been cast but unfortunately he's not who we (fans) were thinking he would be. Sigh. Still it's a great watch and I'm looking forward to the next installment.

Straight from the sour success of capturing the freighter Arcadia and the incoming attack by Umbrella Corporation forces, Alice (the undying Mila Jovovich) is torpedoed straight back into ultimate undead warfare. After capture by the Red Queen, Alice finds herself locked down in an underground (or rather under-ice) research facility, which tests outbreak scenarios on cloned populations, despite having almost no safeguards whatsoever, which would allow for the situation control. Albert Wesker (Shawn Roberts) reappears to switch allegiance to humankind, disabling Alice's prison and sending in Ada Wong (Bingbing Li) to assist with her escape. Meanwhile reinforcements come from above in the shape of Leon S. Kennedy (Johann Urb), Barry Button (Kevin Durand) and the ex-basketball star, current special op Luther West (Boris Kodjoe). Together they must break Alice out from this deadly complex...Despite all its faults and dumb-downed premises the Resident Evil franchise has always been - for lack of a better word - entertaining, even captivating. Action sequences performed with flair, whilst the endless charisma of heroine Alice makes for easy and endlessy appealing watching. Essentially the best video game features on offer with an ever-expanding story and universe to get engulfed by. Nonetheless this time Paul W.S. Anderson fails to follow through on the base promise, basically throwing everything at the audience, except for the kitchen majini. In an attempt to out-explode and out-kill previous outings everything is bigger, stronger and more visceral, but lacks similar charisma and deathly charm. Instead of one Executioner Alice now has to face two, while lickers have seemingly grown in size, stature and durability. Anderson basically rehashes almost all that worked in previous parts, mixes in a bit of "Aliens" iconography, then fails to build it around anything resembling a script. Whereas the action sequences and fights (apparently now heavily inspired by muay thai) are consistently top grade, the same cannot be said about the cast, who apart from several passing grades, fail to deliver quality, instead churning out leaden and uninterested performances. Much probably owed to the lack of plot, which unlike the previous stories always felt focused on an intriguing ordeal.From my side I also sincerely despise the fact that Red Queen has been converted into a malicious computer AI, whilst her ulterior motives set out in the original were logical, obvious, even if homicidal. That said there is still chance to sensibly disclose the logic behind Red Queen's current actions, but this episode in the realm of Resident Evil severely limited faith in Anderson and his overall outlook.

Review title: Loud, dumb and pointless – if even the action fails to thrill, then you know this franchise is well past its 'Afterlife' and close to the point of 'Extinction'
Review_body: Unless you're a die-hard fan of the video game, you're unlikely to recall much of the details or for that matter, the fate of the various supporting characters in the previous four instalments of the undying 'Resident Evil' franchise. Nonetheless, a significant part of how much you'll enjoy 'Retribution' depends on your memory of key ones like Jill Valentine from 'Apocalypse', Albert Wesker from 'Apocalypse' and 'Extinction', and Rain Ocampo from the very first 'Resident Evil' – a tall order, in our opinion, from anchor writer/director Paul W.S. Anderson considering how unremarkable and repetitive most of the instalments were.The reunion of these beloved video game characters should portent well for this fifth movie, but unfortunately the joy of their reappearance is short-lived. On one hand, Anderson doesn't bother to help neophytes understand their history with Alice and the Umbrella Corporation; on the other, his film is just too dreadful to give any of these characters the welcoming party they deserve. Yes, if you were disappointed with 'Afterlife', be prepared to relive that same dejection with 'Retribution' - which like the former is a loud, dumb and ultimately pointless exercise.Picking right up after the events of the last film, Alice is once again recaptured by the Umbrella Corporation after her escape to Arcadia, a cargo tanker that was meant to be a last safe haven for what was left of the humans. Brought to an large underground secret facility where each cavernous section is made to resemble one f the major cities of New York, Moscow and Tokyo, Alice finds an ally in Ada Wong (China actress Li Bingbing in her Hollywood debut), a survivor captured by Jill – and by the way, Jill is now an Umbrella agent after being brainwashed using a mind-control device attached at her chest. The plot of any of the Anderson-scripted 'Resident Evil' movies tend to be simple to the point of being simplistic – an apt reflection in fact of the measure of his scriptwriting abilities really – and 'Retribution' is no different. Here, Alice and Ada are teamed with five rogue members of the resistance led by Leon (Johann Urb), who infiltrate the facility with the intention of detonating it from within. Evade the Red Queen's (oh yes, she makes a return as the ultimate villain here) armies, rendezvous at the place called the 'submarine pens' and get to the surface before the bombs go off – that's about as complicated as the story goes.Of course, the point of these 'Resident Evil' movies was never story or perhaps even character – but one will be hard pressed to find the action sequences redeeming too, and that is regardless of whether you have been a fan of Anderson's slo-mo stylistics. Yes the slo-mo accompanied with rock music shots are still here (and if it's any consolation, toned down a little from 'Afterlife's' excess); what however disappoints is the tempo and the choreography, which going by how lacklustre both are here, seems to suggest Anderson and his team are fast running out of imagination.Indeed, the somewhat innovative camera angles by Glen MacPherson that maximise the third dimension where possible fail to disguise the fact that there is not one single memorable action sequence. Most disappointing are Leon and his team's confrontation with an entire hooded army in Moscow's Red Square (especially considering how the area was shut down for the first time just for shooting), as well as theirs and Alice's subsequent run-in with the huge beast known as Licker – there are no shortage of guns or ammunition in both these sequences all right, but simply pumping both out relentlessly without any measure of restraint or strategy isn't exactly exciting or interesting.The best Anderson manages to achieve is an extended one-on-one showdown between Alice and Jill on one hand, and Leon and a Les Plagas-infested Rain on another – but even in what is supposed to be the highlight of the film, the seen-it-done-that combination of slo-mo weapons, slo-mo bullets, slo-mo dodging and a dash of CG-ed anatomy display fails to raise our pulses as much as we had hoped that it would. And like the instalments that have come before it, this one ends on another cliffhanger with Alice restored and another fight looming – not to mention a shoo-in for what could be the title of the inevitable next film, 'The Last Stand' (not to be confused with Schwarzenegger's next movie).As always too, Milla Jovovich remains one of the few – if not the only – reason to watch the movie. Anderson knows just that, which is why within the first ten minutes, we get to see Alice naked save for two white cloths over her front and back – but the real disservice he does to his real-life wife is trying to build more emotion into her character through a contrived subplot revolving around a motherly bond she develops for a hearing-impaired child Becky (Aryana Engineer). Given how stilted the dialogue is, the less is said in the film the better – and nowhere is this truer than in Li Bingbing's case, coming off stiff and wooden no matter how admirable her effort at enunciating her English lines.If even the action fails, then you can pretty much surmise that there is very little reason to catch this. It is also disappointing considering how unambitious Paul W.S. Anderson continues to be with what is the most successful video game to screen franchise thus far, content to rehash the same formula from his last films again and again. No matter how his name has been synonymous with the 'Resident Evil' films, the only hope of an 'Afterlife' that will save this series from 'Extinction' is really a new writer/ director – only that alone is 'Retribution' enough for the lacklustre films both fans and non-fans of the video game have been made to endure. www.moviexclusive.com

Review title: More of the same, "Resident Evil: Retribution" is unfortunately a step down after the previous two entries, but thankfully is far from being the worst in the series.
Review_body: "Resident Evil: Retribution" is the fifth entry in Paul W.S. Anderson's loose (and I mean very loose) film adaptations of the video game series. Although at this point, Anderson has implemented his own agenda for the series, and removed it so far from it's origins, I don't really see them as video-game adaptations anymore. But I digress, because the series' unfaithfulness to its source material is another topic altogether. Let's just focus on the film itself.Milla Jovovich returns as Alice, this time awakening in a remote Umbrella research facility following the events of the previous film's finale. She is greeted by her former enemy, Albert Wesker (Shawn Roberts), who has evidently defected from Umbrella's side after realizing that with their current agenda, there will be no end to Umbrella's evil scheming, which will inevitably lead to the extinction of the human race. Together with a clone of Rain (Michelle Rodriguez) from the first film and a young girl (Aryana Engineer) who thinks Alice is her mother, Alice is forced to navigate a series of experimental test grounds in the facility, modeled after major world landmarks, to escape.The acting is pretty much par for the course. There are some good performances and some bad. Jovovich is as charming, sexy and cool as ever in the role of Alice, and this film thankfully forces her to stretch her emotional range a bit more than prior films, due to her relationship with the girl. Roberts is flat as Wesker, though, due to his limited screen time and odd delivery of dialog. Rodriguez is a joy to have back, although her roles (since she portrays multiple versions of herself) aren't well developed. Engineer is a lot of fun as the little girl. Supporting roles from the likes of Johann Urb, Kevin Durand and Sienna Guillory range from decent to poor, unfortunately.I found the writing and direction to be a step down, however. I hold the previous two films ("Extinction" and "Afterlife") in a decent regard, and see them as probably the best the series has to offer- they were tightly written, well-directed and a lot of fun, even though they weren't particularly good films. This movie feels more dead on arrival, though. The script is very rushed, characters are much more under- developed, and it's actually quite bland. It's too much of a paint-by- numbers situation. The direction also isn't quite up to snuff. Even though I found the direction of the prior film distracting, due to its obvious overuse of gimmicky 3D, this film just feels... assembled and without character, and I honestly would have preferred the gimmicky direction of the fourth film, since it at least had style. This just doesn't feel like the work of a filmmaker that is fully invested.The rest of the production also feels as though less effort was put in. Set and costume design ranges from great to awful, and everything feels more generic than ever. The musical score is not memorable in the slightest, nor is it particularly compelling outside of the fantastic opening credits theme. The only real step-up was the visual effects, which were actually very good for the most part. Particularly in the new variation of the "Licker", a creature seen in the first two films. While it was never convincing in those movies, here, it's fully realized and looks quite realistic.It's really a shame. Although I was not a particularly big fan of the first two films (in fact, I outright hated the second film), I was very entertained and quite taken by the third and fourth films, due to their fun, action-packed atmosphere. This was definitely a step down, and a step in the wrong direction, and arguably the second weakest film in the franchise. Though thankfully it is nowhere near the disaster that the second film was.I still am curious to see the sixth (and allegedly final) entry in the series, but after this film, I most certainly won't be as excited as I could have been. "Resident Evil: Retribution" gets a very mediocre 5 out of 10. Strictly for fans and nobody else.

Review title: The Retribution is now at hand
Review_body: I just saw Resident Evil:Retribution tonight and I tell you what it was a thrill wild from start to finish.Many characters from the video game make their film debut along with returning favorites.I was glue to my seat from the start to the finish of the movie and it was worth the price of the movie ticket to see this movie.The story take places following the events of Resident Evil:Afterlife where we see our heroes again fighting for their lives.The Movie has Alice (Milla Jovovich) return and now she is in a place where Umbrella can control whatever they want create whoever they want, using clones to test Alice.One is where Alice is a mother to a little girl named Becky (Aryana Engineer) and her husband is Todd (Oded Fehr) however things change fast for Alice as she soon discover she is in a world that Umbrella created.However she is soon join by Ada Wong (Bingbing Li) who convince her to work with her in order to survive the nightmare game that Umbrella started.The movie main villain is Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory)who is under mind control thanks to the Red Queen, she wears a device on her chest just like Jill did in Resident Evil 5.She is join with her team One (Colin Salmon) Carlos (Oded Fehr) and Rain (Michelle Rodriguez) to take out Project Alice at all cost.However another team send by Albert Wesker (Shawn Roberts) lead by Leon S.Kennedy (Johann Urb),Barry Burton(Kevin Durand), Sergei(Robin Kasyanov)and Luther West (Boris Kodjoe) to help Alice and Ada survive the Umbrella monsters.We see the returns of the Axeman, Lickers and of course the zombies who are now like animals.I got to say they really did a lot to make the movie feel like the game and they took a few cut scenes from the game and made them into the movie which is a awesome way to show respect to the Resident Evil Games.The action is really intent and pack a wallet and you can never guess what happens next so my advice is go see Resident Evil Retribution you will not be sorry.I know I am not sorry there is very a moment rest in the movie just when you think the thrill is over here come more thrills it like one creature after another.It just keeps you on the edge of your seat and believe me you will not be sorry you saw this movie.I give Resident Evil:Retribution a 9 out of 10 really ranks up there with the other movies My name is Alice and this is my world

I've been a long time fan of the Resident Evil series even when people criticized them left and right. I thought they were really entertaining, stylish and inventive. Until now. There is no way I can stick up for this movie or any reason I'd even want to. I can't really give you a synopsis cause I'm not even sure what I just watched. All I can say is that it was huge disappointment in every facet possible. Despite the silliness of the previous films they always grounded themselves in some type of realism within the reigns of its premise. This entry doesn't even feel like it's a part of the same franchise. Gone is the fun and it's been replaced with ritzy production values and no discernible storyline. It's a movie based on a video game in which they are actually part of a video game and nothing is really happening. Despite a somewhat promising start with a cool reverse battle sequence, a best of franchise film reel and an inventive and even a little scary trip into suburbia we than move on to the supposed purpose of the film which just doesn't make sense at all. I mean the choices are just astoundingly bad why make the little girl deaf and the film filled with sign language, why set it in this underground facility, why is all of this happening, with this type of technology how does the remaining human population even have a chance, how is Wesker alive and why is he good now? he's not human??? None of these questions will be answered and lets not even discuss the frustratingly awkward scenes like one in which one of the good guys has a double unnecessary death, an uninspired nod towards the Alien franchise and repetitive scenarios that get less effective the more you see them (really the squid face things). Also, the acting has never been good in the Resident Evil series but Milla Jovovich had evoked a cool sense of fierce heroine, this time around she just seems plain bored as do the other actors. Filled with insipid dialogue, questionable plotting,overlong pacing, a weird bad movie from the 90's score, mediocre fight choreography (except for the scene with the chain) and a crapload of wasted potential this movie just feels like a bad dream. Sometimes, when I'm really looking forward to a movie I'll dream about it the night before and it will be horrible well this is what this feels like. Because in no possible way, what I just watched is a resident evil movie. Despite all of my complaining the movie does have some decent scenes the suburbia one I brought up before was kinda neat, another featuring Ada and Alice against 2 ax men and the chain fight in Tokyo. Besides that it's all just a big plodding waste of existential cinematic trash. A brainless, soulless unintentionally funny horror/action/sci fi hybrid that despite a larger budget,returning cast members and more impressive production values feels like an overlong filler episode that leaves me with a big question mark. Why has this happened to my beloved franchise???

Review title: worse than previous sequels, only half of movie is good
Review_body: I only liked good graphics and ideas of such graphics, it is modern, lots of illusions and technology, ideas. Also good final location - the white house, which reminds me of Angel has Fallen movie. Also bit of exhibition, flirting, egoism, emotions. Also good to see old characters. But the story is completely nonsense. No continued, not clear, not interesting, but just random, sudden, twisted. There is nothing to expect in newer sequels except if it gets much different and better than this one.

Review title: Decidedly less rubbish than the last few.
Review_body: The first Resident Evil is one of my all time favourites. Then, unsurprisingly, each film took a step towards utter rubbish. This offering goes back to its Resident roots and plays out a little more like a computer game.Like normal, Alice runs and kicks and runs and shoots and takes a good beating. Zombies, mutants and Lycra clad vileness's are never in short supply. The guys who do the bullet-time effects, who I'm sure are paid by the hour, make a killing from this film.The plot is stupid, the acting and dialogue cheesy. The action predictable and in places monotonous.BUT saying all that they never intended to remake Citizen Kane here. The premise is set out right from the start in plain English: Alice is here, she needs to get over there, kill a million bad guys along the way, set up for next sequel. The film sticks to this premise rigidly, so really it is your own fault if you carry on watching and are disappointed.The setting works well and gives a the director a lot of scope to legitimately empty out his box of CGI toys.The ladies look lovely, the zombies look disgusting and in ninety minutes they get through World War 2's supply of bullets. If this sounds good to you, then happy days!

Well I hate to say this but you really do need knowledge of the video game and all previous four films to understand what goes on here. This franchise is one long story and I must say its been handled well with great continuity and an exciting plot, a real hook to the chops that drags you in.The plot continues yet again from the cliff hanger ending of the previous installment, once more invincible Alice is running from the Umbrella Corp and trying to save mankind. Once again she has a new team of allies to get splatted and eaten one by one as, yet again, she escapes another Umbrella facility, this time under the sea.You do get the impression they have run out of ideas for this new film. All the previous films have a memorable setting, almost like levels in a video game believe it or not. The first film was in the Umbrella Hive facility, second film was a suburban setting in Raccoon City, third film was a desert setting and the fourth film was in a prison setting. This new film is just in another Umbrella facility which happens to be under the sea, but that's it, they toss in lots of other testing zones within the facility just to show as many zombie battle locations as possible which seems cheap.I also didn't really like the inclusion of old characters from past films in zombie/clone form. Again this just seemed a little cheap trying to revive past success (sort of success) from the previous films by sticking in the old characters.In my previous reviews I have mentioned that these films have pretty much copied the basic Aliens survival plot with a team of...survivors. Funnily enough this new fifth film actually goes one step further by giving us a Ripley and Newt subplot rip off right down to even copying an alien...errr I mean Licker pinching Alice's little girl and cocooning her! We then get an almost identical dialog sequence with Alice telling West the kid is still alive and she's going after her like it or not. Oh and a mechanical facehugger bit too. Jesus Anderson lets not actually steal scenes now!Speaking of the Licker, this giant one is actually pretty cool, looks down right nasty and bites peoples heads off with spurting blood! nice. The CGI wasn't too bad either, its just in the end its a complete anti climax once invincible Alice finds it.The new team for zombie chow time isn't as good as previous films either. They don't last too long for starters so we don't get to know them, they're just a small team of blokes who are trying too hard to be butch. Leon is crafted well and looks like his video game counterpart but my god does the actor try for the Eastwood thing. The only other guy of interest is Barry who isn't as pretty as Leon but much more guff and gritty but both of course have huge arms, why wouldn't they? The other two guys we find out nothing and don't see much either, where as Alice's new best friend Ada Wong is a nice sexy double act for the chaps. She does everything in a dinner dress too! (doesn't she ever get cold in that?! she's in the Arctic!).This is probably the most video game-like film of the franchise with its internal test zones and duplicated characters all over the shop. It doesn't hold in your memory like the previous films with its bland setting plus there's the usual plot issues like why Wesker wants to now help mankind, I thought he was a super mutant monster thingy and how come the zombies are now almost intelligent to the point where they can hunt underwater! Isn't that kinda checkmate in terms of places left to go? Las Plagas parasite? you see you gotta know the game background somewhat, or so I've read.Of course by now we all know not to look into these things too much with this series. In terms of action, excitement, violence and plot surprisingly, this film does deliver. I must also admit to LOVING that final sequence from the White House, surely most people got a kick outta that enticing visual tease. It looked like a Peter Jackson inspired sequence for the horror genre, my interest levels are rising.6/10

Review title: Resident Evil 5: Retribution seeks in a distant past some references to build its plot, but the excess of action tires the audience
Review_body: The best feature of the feature film by Paul W. S. Anderson offers are references to games. The narrative is built to look like a game. There are stages - each set in a different country, with different bosses and enemies for each - virtual transitions, new weapons or powers unlocked at each new stage, among other elements taken directly from video games. The whole movie has the look of a Playstation game, from photography, to costumes and characters from the game universe. In addition to Alice and Jill Valentine, join the franchise old acquaintances from the games, who had never shown up in cinema. Ada Wong, Leon S. Kennedy and Barry Burton are examples of this, gaining space in the films to the delight of fans of the franchise.After so much running and running, it's really hard to get a sense of where our protagonist Alice (Milla Jovovich) really is, but suffice it to say that her quest for revenge against the Umbrella Corporation continues unabated, which here imprisons Alice in a kind of complex that, you see, it simulates experimental realities that are very similar to the game phases that need to be won in popular electronic games. Once again, Alice will have help to escape this challenge, as she will come across (in a clever trick of the script) with the return of some familiar faces of the franchise.Right away, "Retribution" shows what it came from: a burst of visual effects. Carrying on the legacy of "Afterlife", 3D is widely used. However, it seems that Paul Anderson learned from the exaggerations of the previous film. The strategy of making things "fly" in the audience's face is used more modestly and when it is done, it has a less obvious impact than it did in the previous film. Slow motion is also used more intelligently, at times when the effect is needed. The opening scene is unusual and has a very positive effect - it's like we're inside Alice's mind, trying to piece together a recent memory. Not only does the feature film start right where the previous one left off, it explains the entire heroine saga so far. If you haven't watched the other films, you won't be parachuted into history, even if it's not that complex. It is the first clue to Anderson's tendency to relocate in "extra-film" everything - contextualization, exposure - that does not refer to the action itself. In one scene, where Jovovich teaches Michelle Rodriguez how to use a gun, she says, "It's like a camera, you just point and shoot." This phrase synthesizes Anderson's work - a vision of cinema at once simple and simplistic -, which treats diegetic space as the domain of action and action alone.Perhaps it is thinking about this that Paul W. S. Anderson promotes in this fifth film the return of a figure that was absent since the first feature, the Red Queen artificial intelligence. The sinister computerized little girl (now played by Megan Charpentier) is not only the main element of the "extra-film" in Retribution, giving information that situates and moves the plot, but also behaves like the master of the game, triggering scenarios and bosses. -stage every mission from Alice and her friends. The fact that Retribution is set entirely in an Umbrella test facility, from which the heroine needs to flee, obviously gives the film a game face, but it is more in Anderson's direction choices than in the script itself that this kinship is established in fact.Despite the crazy proposal to conduct the story in an underground Umbrella complex used for simulations, the plot actually makes sense. Unexpectedly, the installation's existence, construction and purpose are explained, a rarity in Anderson's scripts so far (with the exception of the first). In the end, the idea of "global evil" (which theoretically has been around since RE3: The Extinction) is somewhat exaggerated. Even if we visit Tokyo, Moscow, New York and Raccoon City, the changes of scenery are not so relevant. In the sequences where the characters are in these cities, the location itself doesn't seem to make a difference, since the biggest interaction is not with the environment, but with the creatures. The proof of this is that the sequel in Raccoon City, with the simplest scenario, is one of the most interesting. Meanwhile, in NY the Axemen steal the show and the giant Licker makes you forget you're in Moscow.Once again, the filmmaker explores as much as he can the beauty of his wife, Jovovich, placing her in situations, clothes and poses that evoke only mildly masturbatory images for the male teenage audience (but without showing too much, unfortunately). The promise of a human Alice is definitely fulfilled. Finally, Milla Jovovich showed a more interesting, more empathetic character than the "killing machine" of previous films. In "Afterlife" Alice was supposed to show her human side after losing her powers, but all that was shown were sequences of impossible feats, not worthy of mere mortals. Yes, Alice from "Retribution" is still the badass who kills zombies with impossible stunts and unnecessary explosions, but the fifth feature shows that there is a woman there inside that thick shell. This impression is not restricted to scenes with "Suburban Alice", but also with "Real Alice" and using a child to bring out the sentimental side of the character was an excellent strategy. What is strange is this human side awakened by Becky not causing any kind of commotion in Alice when she sees her friends who died at Umbrella's hands being used as clones to hunt her down.While there is better development for Alice, again, the secondary characters are completely smothered by her presence, especially when considering Leon and Barry. Requests to bring the character from RE4 to the movies were finally granted, but the script doesn't allow the character to be explored, known and become empathetic. Still talking about game characters, Ada Wong is definitely a standout. Li Bingbing manages to get very close to the spy, despite lacking sensuality. The character is better constructed and explored by the script than Leon and Barry, mainly because of constantly sharing the scene with Alice. However, at a certain point in the film, Ada loses space and prominence - we practically forget that bitch in the red dress is one of Albert Wesker's main agents. While Ada is a surprise, Jill is a disappointment. Sienna comes in as the featured villain, which supposedly makes her an important character in the plot, but what has happened to her since RE2: Apocalypse is unknown. When and how was she captured? Since when is it controlled? Sienna had said in an interview that, like Jill from RE5, she would be aware of her actions while acting against her will. At no point was this shown. Luther could have died in "Afterlife", as we came to think, since his participation is insignificant. Chris and Claire are named, but after the battle in Arcadia and the destruction of the Umbrella compound, I'm not sure how Paul Anderson will explain a possible return of the two to the plot.The clones' proposal, which was used as a rather lame justification for bringing Michelle Rodriguez, Oded Fehr and Colin Salmon into the cast, was passed over. Wesker is now, we might say, a former villain. Despite not showing any clear intentions (again, the script fails to explain a relevant point), the character is determined to bring Umbrella down and, as in Umbrella Chronicles, put an end to the Red Queen supercomputer. Now, the girl is a kind of Skynet, who controls Umbrella on all its levels - and hates the human race? This is likely to be the loose end of Alice's journey in the next film.A lot can be said about Resident Evil 5, unless it's a boring movie. The action scenes start right in the opening credits - with a bombastic air raid sequence. It's gunfire, zombies, huge monsters, races and car chases, all at high speed and noise like action fans love so much. With that, any kind of development in relation to the central characters is left aside so that there is more space for the adventure. In other words, don't expect to understand who Alice is or who are her friends. They are just instruments for the action to run as smoothly as possible. Again abandoning zombies for much of the narrative, this new chapter in the Resident Evil saga continues what the previous ones had been doing, increasingly moving away from the undead movie label. Here, the villains are Umbrella and the freaks created by the corporation. Zombies are a small part of the whole. Interestingly, brain-eaters are all the rage lately and it even sounds strange that Resident Evil producers don't take advantage of this good moment to fill the story with zombies.During the entire projection, what the director gives us is sequences and more sequences of brawls à la "Devil May Cry" (another Capcom franchise, by the way) that occasionally impress aesthetically, especially due to good 3D photography. But these scenes soon become tiresome and repetitive, not least because the figures we see on screen are extremely two-dimensional, with most serving only to die suddenly or as mere fan service. Well, games can even support unrestrained action because we put ourselves in the characters' shoes, their risk is ours. Here, we have a rather passive experience, with Anderson alternating between unruly slow-motion and abusively fast cuts, like in the final battle in the snow.Despite having a video game look and being a 3D movie series, Resident Evil 5: Retribution seeks in a distant past some references to build its plot: the open endings, which give clear cliffhangers to the sequel, showing how the Earth is after the last events of the War against Umbrella causes chills and fear of what is yet to come, since the sixth part is confirmed, with the release date already set, with what should be the final chapter. The production of Resident Evil is increasingly worn out, carrying a boredom that increases with each new Alice film against the Umbrella corporation.

Review title: Fun and outrageous fifth franchise installment
Review_body: Alice (Milla Jovovich) and the Umbrella corporation are back at it in the fifth installment to the Resident Evil franchise. After the helicopter assault the Arcadia ship led by Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory), Umbrella captures Alice and puts her through torture and experimentation. Alice discovers that she is in a test facility with multiple big city locations including Tokyo, New York, and Moscow. A war has sparked between Albert Wesker (Shawn Roberts) and the rogue artificial intelligence known as the Red Queen. Wesker sends an extraction team to the Umbrella facility to help Alice escape but the Red Queen uses Jill Valentine, more clones, and zombie mutants to try and stop them.During the experimentation, Umbrella convinces Alice that she has a daughter, Becky (Aryana Engineer). The extraction team has a familiar face with Luther West (Boris Kodjoe) and also includes Barry Burton (Kevin Durand) and Leon (Johann Urb). The clones are of familiar faces from previous films including Rain (Michelle Rodriguez), One (Colin Salmon), and Carlos (Oded Fehr). The movie also brings back monsters from previous films including the ax-toting giant and the crawling creatures from the first film. Alice also teams up with another super soldier Ada Wong (Bingbing Li) to take on the Red Queen's zombie and clone army.Check out more of this review and others at swilliky.com

Review title: "Resident Evil: Retribution" manages to be an action film many will find unbearable to sit through
Review_body: I always find it interesting when an action film feels weighted down in tedium. No matter how many things explode on screen or how much people jump around shooting with semi-automatic rifles, it just can't rile up any sense of excitement. These were my thoughts when reflecting on "Resident Evil: Retribution" after weathering through an hour and a half of tired action movie clichés, slow motion cinematography, and 3D gimmicks.Alice (Milla Jovovich) wakes up in an underwater Umbrella facility where she must travel through different T-virus testing simulations to escape. Along the way, she meets up with an associate of Albert Wesker (Shawn Roberts) named Ada (Li Bingbing). She informs her that Wesker is trying to help her escape to join his fight against the Umbrella Corporation and the undead. Wesker also put together a team made up of Leon S. Kennedy (Johann Urb), Barry Burton (Kevin Durand), and Luther West (Boris Kodjoe) to retrieve the two girls.Alice and her rescuers come up against different varieties of the undead as well as a group of familiar faces the Red Queen (Ave Merson-O'Brian) is using to intimidate and fight against them. The team is led by a brainwashed Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory) and made up of clones of Alice's dead associates including Rain (Michelle Rodriguez), Carlos (Oded Fehr) and James "One" Shade (Colin Salmon). Can Alice get to safety and discover why her old opponent Wesker needs her help so bad?I know the movie is based on a video game, but does "Resident Evil: Retribution" have to feel like I'm just watching someone else play it? A script is almost non-existent as the film takes viewers through different simulated "testing" grounds for at least an hour of the 95- minute running time. Just like in a video game, you go into a room with a character, defeat whatever monsters are in it, and then move on to the next one and do it all again. If I wanted to play the game, I would have just rented the latest version and skipped this mess.Director / writer Paul W.S. Anderson found a way to shove as many of the old characters from the other movies into this one through his use of clones as assassins and gunners for the Umbrella Corporation. Besides Michelle Rodriguez's Rain, the other returning actors have little to do except shoot guns while running and jumping around on wires.The CGI and visual effects aren't too bad. However, the final sequence of the movie looks like it was pulled straight off of Capcom's game. It looks ridiculously animated and really closes the film on a negative note. There also seems to be some kind of synthetic sheen over any scenes featuring Jovovich that give them an artificial air."Resident Evil: Retribution" is a disappointing entry in the franchise. I watched "Resident Evil: Apocalypse" after watching this and it just furthermore pounded home how laborious "Retribution" is. Many enthusiasts of these movies may find themselves feeling like they're sitting on a couch with their hands tied behind their backs while being forced to watch a friend play "Resident Evil 6" for an hour and a half. It's just not a very pleasant predicament to find yourself in.

Review title: My name is Nostalgia and I remember everything
Review_body: The fifth movie in the franchise and even the writers have given up on the story and continuity as they fill this movie with every reference possible to the video games but no actual tie in with the games just cheap character substitutes and pointless uninteresting action scenes nothing new here just another cash grab that tied in with the release of the latest game.The movie follows Alice (Milla Jovovich) directly following the events of the previous movie as she has been captured by Umbrella force's that include a brainwashed Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory) and is taken to a secret Umbrella facility where Jill Valentine interrogates her but after the facility losses power Alice escapes her holding cell and looks for a way out where she finds old friends have come to break her out and some old dead friends to keep her from leaving.The movie is filled with CGI backgrounds flashy effects and the usual monsters that are just CGI messes and bunch of fake blood the outfits for Alice and Jill are pretty cool but other than that the rest of the characters look like cheap knockoffs of the video game characters no real effort made to make this movie worth while.I recommend watching this movie just the once I got this movie on Blu Ray for 50p online that's how much its worth just a quick action movie to poke fun at for how bad it is not worthy for a collection though

This review contains spoilers.Resident Evil: Retribution is the sequel to Resident Evil: Afterlife. Resident Evil: Retribution is the fifth movie in the franchise and takes place after Resident Evil: Afterlife. Alice is captured and in a secret Umbrella Corporation laboratory. A team is assembled to rescue Alice in the laboratory.This movie does not fix the poor writing in the previous movies. The movie starts with the attack on the freighter that happens in reverse as an introductory credits scene. The movie then flashes ahead to a clone Alice dealing with a zombie attack in her home. The movie then finally sets up the main arc of the movie with the assembled team infiltrating the arctic base to rescue Alice.In previous movies, the Umbrella Corporation had many baffling events playing into their favor. In this movie, the Umbrella Corporation have a large laboratory in the arctic where they clone city amounts of people to simulate the viruses they have created's effects on a city. This is explained by the Umbrella Corporation selling the viruses to the highest bidder but this only makes sense if the world's countries have not collapsed. By this movie, the world's governments have collapsed and this lab is still in use. People are still being cloned to simulate bio-weapon attacks. This is a central component of the story and it makes no sense.Anybody hoping for a follow-up to characters in the previous movies will not see it here. The characters in the previous movies are ignored to focus on the Alice character. This is not a good choice as Alice was never a developed character. The most character development she got was in the first movie.The action in this movie suffers from the same disadvantages as in Resident Evil: Afterlife. The movie relies too much on 3D where the directing suffers for 2D viewers. The effects in this movie are competently done.This movie does use more characters from the video game series, but they do not resemble their video game counterparts. The movie continues to use their visual style but not their written stories.Resident Evil: Retribution is not recommended. This movie has too many problems to be even entertaining.Grade: D

Review title: Better Than Afterlife, But Not As Good As The First Three
Review_body: Alice has finally been caught by Umbrella, but a team of elite soldiers has been despatched to try and rescue her and bring down the evil Corporation. Aiding Alice in her escape is Ada Wong, an agent who works for Albert Wesker, but hunting them is Jill Valentine, an ex cop whose services has been "attained" by the Red Queen. Together they must battle their way past the hordes of mutants, zombies, and the Red Queen to get their freedom.This installment is basically pure action from start to finish but the action that is here is pretty impressive, with quite an interesting opening sequence. Super slow-mo is back as well, but I felt this time it wasn't overused like it was in Afterlife. I generally love slow motion action scenes but only when they're done properly and in moderation (and in the right scenes of course). However, when it gets overused - like in Afterlife - it tends to get a bit boring and mundane, but Retribution isn't too bad with it.Our favourite mutants are back as well. Licker, who's MUCH bigger and more vicious than before; Executioner (Axeman) returns (Resident Evil's version of Pyramid Head from Silent Hill) and I must admit I loved this character; Majini aplenty, as well as the regular zombies.Storywise, well, the story's pretty much non-existent here, a bit like in Afterlife. The story that is here is pretty messy and it actually does get pretty confusing at times as there is a lot of appearing in & out of different city "scenarios". Quite easy to get lost if you're not paying attention.One good thing about this installment is that we don't have to put up with the awful acting from Wentworth Miller (who played Chris Redfield in Afterlife). Shawn Roberts is back as Albert Wesker but must have had some acting lessons as he's better in this movie than the last.Resident Evil: Retribution is better than Afterlife, but not by much, and I'm sure the 6th movie - which is in the works - will be about the same.

The opening credits looks so promising. Showing us that we are about to see a large action epic. Despite of its ambitious looks, the movie is still stuck with the same problem of the last film. While the film seems to be cool and fun, the adventure refuses to go further than that. It's big and full of action, but most of them are throwbacks from the previous films. Nobody is actually asking for more than seeing Milla Jovovich slaying these zombies, but sometimes we kind of wish to see something new and interesting here. By its intro, Resident Evil: Retribution is ought to be an extraordinary part of the series. Unfortunately, it rather throw stuff at the audience to keep them distracted.The ending of Resident Evil: Afterlife promises that the next installment will be bigger and more explosive than ever. In the ads, it shows that this will be some sort of a warfare adventure. Although it's never a good idea to trust movie trailers, the film becomes disappointing when the plot twists into a smaller and cheaper version of the expected one. Instead of being one of the climatic parts of the series, the film is still stuck at being a sequel that only exists because of its gimmicky use of the modern special effects and the 3D. It hardly has a build up to the story and it has more "jumping off the screen" moments than innovations.Other than its gimmickry, the film brought back some characters from the first three, but only for fan service reason. They also brought some iconic characters from the video game like Leon Scott Kennedy and Barry Burton, but sadly their portrayal is pretty bland. The action just got bigger but there is nothing new about it. We've seen the enemies before. The slow-mos are once again repetitive. It's basically meant to be cool, but in the end it's just another gloss. The only good thing here is Milla Jovovich's fighting, tomandandy's music score, and the special effects.Just like Afterlife, Resident Evil: Retribution is another unnecessary part of the series. It's disappointing because this sequel did nothing but to show some random nonsensical set pieces and bring back some old characters. Some new characters were introduced but they turned out to be useless. I understand that it's about the action and the fans swallowing the awesomeness but it's the same thing all over again. It's like combining all the memorable elements from the first four films and made it into a large scale action fare in 3D. Overall, it's mediocre and a cash-in nonsense. In the end of the film, it reveals that the next film will be exaggeratedly bigger than this one. I hope the next one will finally step up as a true apocalyptic onslaught than being a repetitive sequel.

PREMISE: Alice. Kills stuff. PLOT: Alice. Kills stuff.Viewers hoping for a coherent narrative are advised to try Capcom's Resident Evil cartoons; viewers completely new to the series really have no choice but to let the images simply break over them like tsunamis. Despite 2 or 3 pages of exposition, series writer/director Paul W. S. Anderson clearly assumes that anyone rejoining him at this point is so familiar with both the movies and the various R.E./BIOHAZARD VGs that new characters (Ada Wong; Leon Kennedy) can be ported over from the games, and old characters (Rain; Carlos) resurrected without explanation (Jill Valentine, Albert Wesker and Luther West are back; Claire and Chris Redfield make cameos). Happily, I AM that geekish, so enjoyed the merry-go-round.The CGI FX, which are virtually non-stop, are more varied, energetic, and original than in previous sequels. No more mutant dead dogs, thank goodness, although Anderson remains overly-fond of his tentacles- bursting-out-of-the-mouth shots.The movie is less a script than a series of levels, as Alice, Project Alice, Leon, Ada and their ad hoc teams are dragged through artificial environments adapted from previous installments, from games (notably the new Manhattan and Moscow sets), from any spin-off that isn't bolted to the ground, even from absolutely unconnected franchises (e.g. DAWN OF THE DEAD). Each setting-all controlled by The Red Queen--has its own horde of character clones infected with different strains of the T-Virus and/or Plaga Parasite and its own boss monster adapted from one or another of the games.If...and only if...that paragraph made the least bit of sense, then this movie's recommended.

Review title: Perfect example of what you.... SHOULD NOT DO !
Review_body: Resident Evil, a mythic name in survival horror turn into a brainless action movie... Well this is basically what you have here. If the first couple of movies took liberty and replaced our beloved heroes with a poor character without savour, at least they tried to remain close to the source material. Then the third one was a mess and the rest lost any appeal.This movie dosen't have any plot, its basically a "go from point a to point b" type of movie, pretty much like dragging a middle movie action sequence during an hour and a half... It pretty much feel like they didn't know what to do for the next movie, so they had Paul Anderson's kid or nephew or whatever write something that he tough would look cool on cam... It feel like it. Characters are randomly pop out of nowhere, are nothing except costumes from there video game counterparts, enemies have pretty much the same treatment and this movie just feel like a big mess.If you like the video game, stay away from this movie, its basically like hearing your little sister that have absolutely no talent for singing trying to sing a song you like... it may be the same tune, but damn it has nothing to do in common with it.If you don't like the game, don't care about story and just want good visual effects and action scenes, well it may suit you, cause its the only thing good about it.

This film is definitely the weakest of the franchise so far.The story was really quite weak, and I just couldn't get on board with it at all. I enjoyed that they brought back a few of the cooler characters from the franchise, but they all felt very hollow, there for show and shock value rather than for any real meaning or contribution to the plot.In terms of the dialogue and acting, Retribution falls below the already relatively low standard set by the rest of the franchise.On the bright side I did enjoy the action in parts. There were a few generic bits that were going through the motions, but mostly it was fun. Hopefully, based on the final scene, we are now set up for an action packed sequel.This is a necessary watch as part of the franchise, but it definitely feels like a chore at times.

Review title: They Pull It Off Again, Lots Of Fun
Review_body: The new installment in the Resident Evil saga, Retribution, is a big budget film which intentionally has a low budget feel to it, from the bad acting to the lousy dubbing to the choppy editing to the outrageously unbelievable action, it's a salute to the days when making science fiction / horror was fun. More bullets fly in this one than in the most violent John Woo film, and in addition to crazed zombies this time around we have zombies on motorcycles, zombies with machine-guns and of course giant mutants that tear through stone walls and scream really loudly. Milla is getting older but she's still pretty hot and a lot of her stunts are subtly played for tongue in cheek laughs. It was a wise decision not to take this fifth or is it sixth sequel too seriously, but it was also wise not to make it a comedy on the surface but to play it all with a straight face while things that you might expect from Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror or Machete occur. This is really an example of so bad it's good. I had a lot of fun watching it. Don't listen to the critics. If you're a Resident Evil fan, you won't be disappointed.

Review title: this a movie not worth the time
Review_body: The whole Alice thing and new creatures to wipe out with eye pleasing stunts is starting to get very old, not to add boring.This is the fifth installment in this film series and the third to be directed by Paul W. S. Anderson who also wrote the movie. It features various cast from the old movies like Sienna Guillory (Jill Valentine), Boris Kodjoe (Luther West) and Michelle Rodriguez who played Rain Ocampo in the first film.Retribution also brings back the red queen from the first resident evil, but her must kill attitude makes you wish someone will just put a sock in it. The thing is if you want to enjoy this movie, live your brains at home, and if you are like some (eg me) who finds it impossible to do so, then strap in for a gun fight, hand to hand combat all for apparently no reason.The high note in this film will be Alice; I never get to have enough of Milla Jovovich's portrayal of the character.The movie's story sees Alice (Milla Jovovich) captured by the Umbrella Corporation. She now has to escape from an underwater base in the Arctic Circle, used for testing the T-virus.Rodriguez and Guillory were very much in par with Jovovich's acting and the fight scene between Guillory (Jill) and Jovovich (Alice) was too long, and it was said to have involved more than 200 moves. Directing is no way near perfection; the sad thing is a sixth movie is also being planned.The slow motion and matrix effects were over used and not necessary in some scenes, other slacks were in editing we had scenes taking too long. Anderson and Jovovich also worked together in the movie The Three Musketeers (2011). If you are planning to go watch this movie, you can but just leave your brain at home

It's just like come on every time with this film series, it never ever improves and yet again this movie is a step down from the last outing. We see again a movie full of action, easy to follow yes but fun, my word no, this is awful and that is not a word I have had to previously use on the franchise before. We see this time Alice (Milla Jovovich) fighting yet again, things pick up from where the last film left off, down to the second actually and from then on we see a mass adventure that goes nowhere and only provides glimpses of some decent action choreography that just doesn't mean anything among all the terrible lines spewed out. The man behind this all is Paul W. S. Anderson who is a producer on this film as well as the director and writer, and oh how he screws this one up, a movie I feel just didn't need to be made, or actually, just made well!Jovovich is typical in her role as Alice and for those who have come to get used to her acting it is same old, really though I do feel the writing makes her feel worse as an actor though. This movie is obsessed with throwing things from the past right back at you and none of them work, it feels like Anderson ran out of ideas within the first 5 minutes and just couldn't be bothered to make something even half decent. The plot is full but flimsy, in fact so full it is that by the end it is breaking off and becoming increasingly run of the mill with every passing second. We see some new faces and some we have seen before but truly none of them work, the villains seem like the shoddiest creation of this movie(the story isn't far off though).Anderson just doesn't seem to get it that he's not making good movies, sure you can make a few poor one's and they'll blow over eventually, but this is something else. The series started out under average and was poor too but never was it truly very bad but now it is has reached that and maybe it is the annoyance I have for this series or that it just gets worse every time but, I just had to describe this as awful. Let's talk about the technical points and the CGI is OK at times but even that is used stupidly, the sets are something from a weird dream that is also a nightmare and all the time I just felt what a waste of not only production designers, but also of imagination.I'm not going to rant for nine pages about how I hated this, I'm going to leave it for you to see if you haven't all ready, I know even some like these kind of OTT action movies but this one really does not stand out and can't even rank well among it's not even OK predecessors. I hope one day Anderson can look back on his career and realise this was not a good move, I even hope he can make one film where everyone likes it and says "Hey great job Paul" and not "Remember when you made those dumb zombie movies Paul, they were real bad". So yes, Resident Evil Retribution, a movie that is hard to recommend unless you're either really into zombies or really into Milla Jovovich, and even then there are many better zombie movies out there, and movies with Jovovich in that are also much better.

Review title: Either these keep getting better or...
Review_body: My God this movie is so amazing (in 3d). Just pure action advances the ongoing story slightly. If you're giving this a poor review, why the hell are you watching in the first place. It's the 5th one, if you didn't like the first 4 stop wasting your time you masochistic weirdo. Enjoy the movie, 420 + 3d makes this a guaranteed good time. I would say my 2nd favorite after the first, just because of rehashing different villains from previous installments and pure action with Ludacris 3d.

Review title: A Reflection on the franchise itself - All Action, of course
Review_body:
In what is not the last, but is likely the least of installments, we see more of the same and no real movement forward. An epic intro, followed, as always, by Alice's story, or the "previously on Resident Evil", going into another weakly outlined, shallow story, this time tying in more with the very first movie, bringing back multiple characters, albeit some of them are a little different. In a way, "Retribution" is an ode to the franchise itself at that point, and, well, wasn't necessary.We learn that the situation at the end of "Afterlife" has led to Alice being captured, and tampered with by none other than Umbrella Corporation, which is now solely controlled by the Red Queen, the AI from the beginnings of the franchise. Similarly to the first part, decent portion of events take place inside one of their huge facilities, though it's not claustrophobic no more - the spacious facility is meant for simulations, so various settings are explored. Anderson has tried to make it all fun with use of various terrains, locations, different infected etc., but, again, all in the name of variety in action and eye candy, not story and, frankly, neither atmosphere. I'm not sure if I have seen zombies riding cars and jumping motorcycles before...
The nature of the system of characters don't change, old and new pals, acting cool, come to rescue. Ada Wong existed for exposition and fights, Leon got entirely disrespected as a character, and so were a few other one-function, one-off guys. Characters of "Retribution"don't evolve, except to die or partake in paper thin melodrama. Milla continuously shows devotion to the franchise and Alice, having more range this time around, as one plot line deals with her living the "normal" life as a suburban mom right when the apocalypse starts. I complimented the miniboss in "Afterlife", and they literally pulled the same guy again, this two of them for an action scene. Big scary boys from "Apocalypse" also made second appearances. C'mon guys, to have more of exactly the same wasn't my point. The franchise's standard entertainment value and where it's rooted, in flashy, occasionally even reasonably tense, action sequences, is still alive and well, as is the lack of depth. By the third act, the formula has become a little tiresome, and you find yourself slightly relieved when the climax has passed.If you're looking for a for an action packed adventure (with a sense of emptiness), this here is a good contender, dramatic, loud, flashy, pointless. My rating: 5/10.

Review title: Delivers what you would expectaction, action and some more action
Review_body: This movie is the 5th installment in the Resident Evil series. Why would you want to watch this movie? Why would you want to watch any Resident Evil movie come to think about? Good actingnope. Intelligent and intriguing plotabsolutely not. Zombiesyep. Actionmost definitely yes! Anything elsewell if you're member of the younger part of the average male population you probably watch it for Milla Jovovich as well.Now that we have established the baseline for the movie, does this movie deliver? The answer to that is, without a doubt, YES! This film delivered exactly what I expected of it. As I mentioned it is the 5th movie in the series and the entire series is sprung from a video game in the first place so it should really be no surprise that the film is one long video game action sequence sporadically interrupted with some dialog. Yet a lot of people seems to expect something else and judges the movie by those expectations.I think those really low rating are quite unfair. The movie does indeed deliver what I think you should expect. A lot of the action scenes are marvelous. The slow motion scenes are well done and enjoyable unlike some movies where they are just annoying. The zombies and other monsters are good. And yes, I confess that, although I'm hardly among the younger part of the male audience anymore I do like watching Milla Jovovich jumping around in the scenes in those ridiculous skin tight suits.If I should complain about anything it would be that I sat through half the movie being annoyed that nobody would get the, painfully obvious, idea to rip that red mind control gizmo off Jill's chest. When it was finally done in the end it was like "did you really have to take that long to get that idea into your head you dumb bastards".I cannot really give the movie a top rating since it does lack much of a story after all but I certainly think it is worth 7 out of 10 stars. I enjoyed myself a lot while watching it. The ending is the usual video-game-movie cliff-hanger and I really hope they make another sequel now when Alice got her powers back. That she lost those was one of the big downers for me in one of the previous movies in the franchise.

I enjoyed this movie. It was different from other parts. The beginning unnecessary rewind scene in which too much VFX was used, was fun to watch. Casting and acting was average. Plot was was little better. Overall, enjoyed it.

Review title: If a bad fan fiction writer got a multi million dollar budget
Review_body: Paul WS Anderson takes "style over substance" to its limit in his fifth installment in the Resident Evil movie franchise. At least half the action scenes are in slo-mo, similar to the previous franchise entry. What might be more stylish than slo-mo? Slo-mo in reverse! And that is exactly what the opening sequence delivers; it wastes almost 5 whole minutes picking up from the previous film: Umbrella Corporation forces attack the ship that Alice and her friends are on, there is lots of shooting then Alice is blown into the water. All that IN REVERSE, then forward again. Alice is captured and trapped in a vast underwater facility that houses replicas of the world's major cities like New York and Moscow. It is revealed that Albert Wesker (the main villain so far) has splintered off from Umbrella corporation (which is now being run by the artificial intelligence program "Red Queen"). Alice must escape, but not before fighting her way from one movie cliché to another.For those new to the Resident Evil movie franchise, it is everything you'd expect from a skewed piece of fan fiction. Paul WS Anderson's wife, Milla Jovovich, stars as the ultimate Mary Sue character named Alice; effectively reducing main characters from the Resident Evil video games to supporting roles. Stripped of her superpowers, Alice is still unnaturally agile, sickeningly strong and uncannily durable. Bullets magically miss her, convenient tools and weapons appear to her when she needs them and her guns never run out of ammo. If all the slow motion scenes were played at normal speed, this already short movie will be a lot shorter. Its actual narrative is already THAT thin, not to mention that most of it is a pastiche of scenes and concepts ripped off from other films. James Cameron's Aliens, Zack Snyder's Dawn of the Dead and many others are blatantly and shamelessly plagiarized. In what I suppose is meant to be a "smart" reference of a reference, Paul WS Anderson rips off the "X-Ray vision bone crunching" fighting gimmick that was used in 2009's Mortal Kombat video game (not surprisingly, Anderson directed the very first Mortal Kombat movie).Within the zombiefied narrative, we are treated to more "startling" revelations that only serve to muddle up the already messy story of the Resident evil movie franchise. New creatures pop out of nowhere without any conceivable explanation, a new zombie infection called "las plagas" is introduced, and we get unsurprising origin of Alice and who she truly is. Speaking of zombies, they feature very rarely in this movie; or at least the traditional human zombies that Resident Evil is known for. Giant Mutant creatures only make occasional appearances as "mini-bosses" for Awesome Alice to kill (as usual). Most of the fighting involves Alice, former Umbrella operative Ada Wong and a mercenary team led by Leon Kennedy going up against cloned Umbrella troopers including a few familiar faces.Yes the special effects are top notch (considering its huge budget), and the slow motion will keep ramming that fact into your face. But other than that, there is little else to enjoy about this movie (perhaps some will get off on a near nude Milla Jovovich's torture scene). There is no sense of peril for the characters and even the fight choreography is more like dancing than fighting.With a story that feels like a filler episode in a TV series, shallow characters, blatant plagiarism and a overall "been there done that" feel, Resident Evil Retribution shows a zombie movie franchise in the literal sense; the same thing that just keeps coming back from the grave, more mutated than ever. What we have, at best, is a multi million dollar tech demo for fight choreography, slo mo cinematography and 3D.

Very heavy on the CGI, which is all very well done by the way, I'm guessing a lot of green paint was used. I think just about every fight sequence was shot in slow motion; I'm not sure why but for me it didn't add any excitement. Nobody will win any prizes for the performances, although I thought Michelle Rodriguez as Rain did a pretty good job. Okay, from an entertainment perspective, yes, it did its job; an easy to follow plot that has plenty of action and some very pretty ladies; this red blooded male was not disappointed on that front. On the down side; it does look like you're watching someone else playing a first person shooter video game. It's left wide open for another sequel (hopefully the last one), so I guess there will be more And I will be watching.SteelMonster's verdict: RECOMMENDED (Purely for entertainment If this is your sort of thing that is)My score: 5.7/10You can find an expanded version of this review on my blog: Thoughts of a SteelMonster.

This installment of the Resident Evil series takes the convoluted story of the first four movies and throws it out the window, to replace it with an even more nonsensical story. I have no idea any more who is whom, why characters do what they do and what the point is. Still, lots of shooting, fights and explosions. That's good at least.

Review title: Same mistakes, same pointlessness, same typical Anderson film
Review_body: "Resident Evil: Retribution" is a 2012 action horror film written and directed by Paul W.S. Anderson starring Milla Jovovich and Sienna Guillory. After the disasterpiece the previous installment has been, the series even more moves on as an action flick rather than horror film and loses even the smallest rest of a soul it had. You already know my profound aversion towards the probably worst director working Hollywood, Paul W.S. Anderson and if I went deeper into how much I dislike him, my reviews would become sort of repetitive. Speaking of repetitive, this film here is once again on the same abysmally low level of quality. If there's nothing new to add and the film suffers from the exact same flaws over and over again, how am I supposed to not repeat myself? Sigh. As usual, the film wastes most of its runtime with absolutely useless nonsense and pointless scenes. Not only does it have a completely questionable slow motion intro scene, it also features a totally needless recap sequence that takes around ten minutes of a ninety minutes feature film. You know where this is going? From there on, I knew that I was in for some extremely boring garbage. Again. What comes then is not slightly better. This man will always remain a mystery to me, it's strangely fascinating. How can you film scenes that are lasting so painfully long while they're having absolutely nothing to say? There's happening so much and yet so little. It's clearly something happening, but not interested enough or coherently explained why. Or what. Fact is, Anderson has the dolorous ability to write and film sequences without any meaning behind it. Strangely, those sequences last for a whole film when he's in charge of the whole creative process. In addition to that, he once more proved that he can connect the previous film in the sloppiest way possible. He tries to create a certain continuity and fails miserably, all the while losing some actually important characters. Somehow and not further mentioned, the Redfields have disappeared without a trace. Gone with the winds. Simply vanished. Isn't that proof enough that this man is obviously not capable of making a great film? How often do I have to point this out? Sigh. You think the beginning is already the worst? Sorry to disappoint you, but it's all downhill from there. Aside from the evident predilection for filming his wife in full nudity over and over again, he also has not the simplest form of an understanding of enacting decent action sequences. Basically, I love some action films and it's not impossible to have exciting choreographies (the "John Wick" series, for instance), but what is shown here is just laziness in its purest form. Come on, all the so-called action sequences are literally just monotonous gunfire without any interesting movements or any form of choreography. The choreography is that there's none. The abstruse "plot" that results from an mediocre yet actually promising premise is not much better. It's again evident how Anderson tries to desperately keep up the connection with the games, although that train has left the station long ago. How it does it? Well, his general measure is to bring in beloved characters from the games, make them totally irrelevant and to not give him the slightest touch of spotlight. I'm obviously talking about the legendary Leon S. Kennedy who like Jill was degraded to an underused side character and looks like some random dude in his cosplay costume. The same applies to Ada Wong and Barry Burton. Disgracing the source material so severely just to still call it Resident Evil. You still call yourself a fan, Paul? You don't seem to be at all. What the film offers from there on is again nothing short of sleep inducing trash no-one ever asked for. One repetitive shootout follows another and along the way it features utterly stupid character choices and plot decisions. Why did they bring back characters from the other films as clones? Why did Alice all suddenly care so much about that little girl that's nothing but an artificially created clone she has zero connection to? Why did she leave behind her saviours in order to save her? Even worse: Why is Wesker all suddenly a renegade agent and how is the Red Queen still alive? Those unnecessary and unexplainable features are the true horror of this film. Oh, and the final fight is just a disgrace to the characters, ludicrous and dolorously unrealistic. On top of that, they even throw mud at the Las Plagas and ... it even turns into Mortal Kombat? Don't ask me why, but ... somehow? Oh, and the ending definitely doesn't mean anything good. That's for sure. All in all, this entry is repetitive, dull, boring, meaningless, pointless and hasn't learned from any of its mistakes. While the previous one was some sort of guilty pleasure this one again falls under the category of "simply unentertaining" and it's another evidence of Paul W.S. Anderson's inability to do anything correctly. It's the definition of stupidity and nothing short of totally forgettable action garbage. Painfully dreadful.
The franchise is what it is by a fifth film, you get what you sat down to watch

Review title: I wrote detailed reviews for the first 4 installments
Review_body:
If possible this would get a -3.....(I don't care how much afterlife made, this is a horrible script please burn it, as you should have done with Afterlife).If you read my 1/10 star rating for Afterlife you get the point
Unfortunately it's not a minus 10 to positive 10, because this was such a rewrite anything you thought you knew from the first 3 movies just toss out.The name of this should be Resident Evil The New Evil.....
1. Why she would talk or work with Wesker makes zero sense. The second they think he exploded and they're safe they're bombarded by an aerial Armada and she wakes as a prisoner again!2. I honestly don't know why they want to kill her or shut her up.3.
