I sense ethical dilemmas that have zero to do with the story surrounding cloning and AI or real intelligence that gets irritating with an irrelevant attachment to the cloned little girl who's cloned Mother (Alice' clone) got killed by back to regular zombies.4. During her staged rescue forget about the Chopped Meet Version of the Hulk or where he came from?In Fake Moscow the rescue team is under attack by a well organized and physically coordinated and weapon wielding Russian Zombie platoon HOW DOES THAT HAPPEN WITH ZOMBIES?5. It was obvious from Claire in the previous film you had to get the cyber mind control device off Valerie's chest so why does that take forever?

Review title: The only evil in this sequel
Review_body: Is that there is nothing new compared to previous films in the series. We see the same story how Alice must reach from point A to point B, the same monsters, zombies with octopus come out of the mouth, the same huge guys with axes, the same room where everything starts, the same weapons, same fight scenes, everything is the same as the previous movies. If it goes on the same idea might make another hundred sequels. I wonder Milla is not tired by the same texts that need to say, or she likes to shoot with the gun in zombies? I'm curious if it will come out in the next movie or will give away the role to another actress?If I talked bad about this movie, the great part is that I was bored, I admit I was a bit sleepy but has managed to keep me awake and watching until the end. We have action, chases, shootings but still, the same scenario every time will cause fans to lose interest in this big-screen adaptation of the well known game.

Rented from Redbox, and struggled to finished the movie. I am not a RE fan but have seen the previous four. While none of them are Oscar contenders, generally it is good for 2 hours of action adventure, millions of rounds of bad shooting, zombies and generally watchable.Oh wow. Whether you are a fan, semi-fan, or even a hater, this movie is such a step down from any of the previous four.Mistake #1 Everything was done in one warehouse, one cul-de-sac of houses, and a whole bunch of computers. I doubt very seriously if Milla Jovovich even had to leave the same room for 85% of the movie. I would not surprised me if all her scenes were done in a couple days, and the computers did the rest. There was no need for costume designers, stunt people, stunt cars, or even makeup people, everything was CGI, including the bruises on the face.Mistake #2 The guys that essentially did all the CGI, also wrote the dialogue. The conversations are on par with the dialogue in a bad porn movie. You will have a hard time finding a conversation involving more than 20 words...total...for both people.In short, this is the world's best movie done with Photoshop, or you could say it would be the winning entry of a movie composed by film students(first year community college students). But for a movie that people pay money for, it was almost as if the producers/directors were purposely trying to find the minimum effort needed to stamp the 'Resident Evil' nameplate to. It would have been better if they advertised it as a comedy.

If you want a movie to feel exactly like a video game, this movie is for you because that's exactly how it feels. I've never seen a movie that felt more like a video game in my life. However, if you're like me and you want your movie to have plots that actually make sense and have a nice flow to them, you probably won't enjoy this movie. It's really upsetting that a franchise that started so well has disintegrated into this. The first two films, I thought were outstanding but the next two were plagued with absurd levels of ridiculousness and this film had the worst plot development I've seen yet. It's unfortunate too because the acting is good enough and the action sequences are entertaining but the cheesy 3D elements and the garbage plot development show just how a terrible director can destroy a movie. I'm glad they're only making one more... though, how they made this many just shows how stupid Europeans actually are.

Seriously, how many of these movies are they gonna make? Like the zombies themselves, the film series based on the popular video game series refuses to die thanks to the ever persistent director Paul W.S. Anderson. While they're certainly no masterpieces, I must admit that I do enjoy watching these movies and they just get crazier every time. Right now, this is by far the craziest of them all! The story is fairly simple: Alice and friends continue to battle their way through hordes of T-virus zombies, terrifying mutants, and the ruthless Umbrella Corporation. This time, however, old faces return to haunt our heroine and make things a little more difficult. Luckily, there are some new faces to help her out in an all-out fire fight. There's plenty to like here. First of all, the action scenes are just awesome with a never-ending line of insane twists coming around here and there. The effects are definitely better this time around to the finest detail and the fear-factor is adequate for those of you who like being scared. Seeing some of the familiar faces from the older films like Michelle Rodriguez was a real treat to watch and the new cast holds up pretty well. The music is also a real pleasure to listen to throughout the film.While the Resident Evil film series is starting to get tiresome with each new sequel, this is overall a fun movie to watch. Definitely worth seeing just for the action and seeing how the story continues. Nothing else much to say, so check it out!

What can one say about beating a dead horse. Based off the ever popular video game series these movies started out as a super power in the syfy/action saga. Tapping Milla Jovovich (Fifth Element, Resident Evil, The Fourth Kind, .45) being the bad ass lead and being simply gorgeous to boot was clever. The first three films in the series were great success's and did superb at the box office, as I'm sure the rest will and have as well. However, the series has gotten off track and the last two films have been terrible in acting and the CGI is an abomination. Do not get me wrong I love me some Milla and the video game is killer, yet the series needs a drastic overhaul and re-boot if they are going to continue.Did I mention Milla Jovovich is stunning.

Review title: Resident Evil delivers action but little else
Review_body: Unlike most of the video game based films, the Resident Evil franchise has managed to keep churning them out. While not all are on par with the fun of the original, they each have had something of their own to bring to the table and the fans that enjoy them really get sucked in. The latest installment Resident Evil: Retribution, sported a trailer that seemed to tease the return of previous characters in the series, but does it have anything new to add to the series? Resident Evil: Retribution follows Alice alongside a resistance movement in her continuing war against the Umbrella Corporation. The latest installment is decent enough, but falls short in a lot of ways becoming the weakest of the series so far. There is a lot to digest here in such a short run time and not all of it works or makes sense. As with most of the films there are a lot of holes in the story, but you let a lot of that go in exchange for the zombie killing action. Here you get tons of action, but still just didn't really have the same vibe as the other films. Jovovich steps into the role delivering the character pretty much exactly the same way she always does, but the same cannot be said for the rest of the cast. Most of them are pretty stiff and feel forced or like they just aren't feeling it. There are plenty of returning creatures and characters, but most of them just didn't feel necessary other than to try and add that missing something. The problem is they don't really do much with most of them and they feel like a wasted opportunity. The location of the film is both good and bad. There were some great opportunities here to do some really cool things with their environment all over the world, but instead it just felt like they really served no point other than to attempt to explain how the T-Virus spread. Yes this info is important, but it could have just been in dialogue without the other aspects, and in some ways it pretty much was which was an overall waste of space. The action was really well done for the most part and there was plenty of it. Easily most of the movie was just gun fights and hand to hand combat which keeps you entertained while suffering through the other nonsense.Originally it was said that the fifth and sixth film would be filmed back to back and it shows here. This isn't a horrible film, just feels more like filler to something else instead of the standalone films with an obvious more to come ending like the others. If you are a fan of the series be sure to check this out, because it defiantly sets it up for another and if done correctly could be a great cap on a fun franchise.http://www.examiner.com/movie-in-dallas/bobby-blakey

Review title: I saw improvements, the second best in the series
Review_body: Well, what I saw in this movie is that it seems our director Paul W.S. Anderson took lessons from the mistakes he did in the previous sequels, so made some improvements. What are those? Firstly after the first film, the focus was shifted from zombie battle to some other sub stories and that caused the story to scatter, in other words lost its focus. In Retribution, we come back to the "zombie" horror which is good. The movie has some good zombie action. The first movie was subtle, solid and stylish, then in the sequels, As for the style, it turned into almost garbage. In this installment, Anderson brings some "art". Remember the suburbia scenes which also reminded me Kill Bill. The movie is not subtle may be like the first one, but at least it is stylish and not superficial like Afterlife. Thus, Retribution is not entertainment without "cinema" Yes there are such movies believe me! You may find the story cliché, you may find the movie shallow, you may find the movie average etc. but at least it is not an "empty" movie. Thirdly, Anderson got rid of "Matrix trend" which is good too. This movie has his own action style. Afterlife was lack of real violence and horror, in this one, you will get these! Except for the first movie, especially the second and the fourth one was pretty boring at times because of lack of action. Retribution is almost non stop action! And it is better action. I always hated that all the sequels had a very ugly monster mostly as the climax, this installment has a different (and better) climax! In Apocalypse and Afterlife, there were some ridiculous moments, this movie avoids that and catches a serious tone. And if you liked the giant hatchet scene from the previous movie, the extended version is here, it was a great scene and this time it was not pointless (Sucker Punch logic, good) Michelle Rodriguez, the problem was her character isn't a well written character, so don't expect "Avatar level" However, to see her was real good. As for 3D, it was worthy, but worse than Afterlife and Three Musketeers. I don't know why. In the second half, the movie has some very cliché moments, but not a big deal. And yes, at times, the movie repeats itself, may be it doesn't add anything new, but I've gotten used to that. It has a better direction, better visuals and even a better, more solid script without any ridiculousness and that's enough for me. As said it is better than all of the sequels and it is like almost a masterpiece in comparison with the recent Underworld Awakening. If Anderson plans to make a sixth movie, I hope he can surpass this one, We have enough disappointments.

Review title: Weakest of the series but still very fun...... Resident Evil Retribution
Review_body:
Resident Evil Retribution the fifth entry in the Resident Evil movie franchise and the weakest in my opinion.
However it's still a very fun and enjoyable entry in to the series with some awesome action and an interesting plot with Alice trying to get out of the Umbrella Prime facility which creates VR world's very interesting and pretty well handled.There some some things that bother about this one which is the reason it's the weakest of the films in my opinion and why I like the other movies better.
This entry just feels like filler to get to The Final Chapter non of the other movies did that and followed on very nicely but could stand alone this one just feels like it's setting up things to come and that's pretty annoying in my opinion.We do get some characters from the game's introduced which is awesome like Leon Kennedy who is handled really well. We also get Ada Wong who I wasn't a massive fan of in the games but she's pretty cool in the films.
Jill Valentine is also back and her story is pretty cool her being controlled by Umbrella was pretty awesome. And her action scenes where bad ass.They do bring back other characters back from previous movies but they are waisted in this movie Rain played by Michelle Rodriguez serves no purpose in this movie and is only in this to remind us of what's happened in previous movies and to be a complication for Alice.However I do really enjoy this movie the story is very interesting and very cool with some great action sequences and Alice is still the interesting character that we all know. And I really like this character she is a great lead character in my opinion.Just a fun movie that i enjoy but I enjoy the other entries in the franchise more. Very fun action and an interesting storyline in a great sequel that leaves you wanting more by the end of the film. I can't wait to see how it ends after this movie.Verdict 7.3/10 very fun and action packed had some flaws and i enjoy the other films more but this is a great entry into this awesome franchise.

Review title: Video game lacking any audience appeal
Review_body: From the opening credits, which show the immediate continuation of the previous film (but in reverse) onwards this feels like watching a videogame that some other unknown person (or perhaps a machine) is playing. Consequently it feels entirely contrived and there is no viewer involvement at any level, as it lacks both the structure and character development of a film story or the participatory element of a videogame one is playing oneself. It has got to the point where there are so many manufactured and or rebooted versions of the Alice figure and other participants that the entire series has lost any meaningful connection for the audience, despite the director's attempt to persuade us otherwise, as the multi-rebooted Alice decides to protect a child who was manufactured for the role of daughter to a manufactured suburban version of her. Basically, with all this cloning, anybody can be destroyed and brought back to serve a plotline that is becoming increasingly absurd. And we all know that clones aren't the real thing, but likely to be programmed by Umbrella, or the Red Queen, or Wesker, to serve some nefarious purpose that I have lost interest in knowing about.

Review title: The best movie of the year.
Review_body: More like the worst movie i've seen all year. Where do I even begin with a stinker like this. I can't believe garbage like this can make 200 million dollars. This film feels like it was slapped together in a couple of months, not even. I didn't think they could make a worse one than afterlife, well it's not that bad, but it still numbs my brain.Let's start with the characters. You would think film has reached an all time low with these actors. This was a fairly big budget film, couldn't they have got better people. The acting is some of the worst I have ever seen, they should feel embarrassed, it is simply atrocious. Did I mention these characters are super-human and can deflect bullets. Take this for example, 6 guys versus 500 umbrella soldiers armed to the teeth, and they lose one guy, to a chainsaw man no less. Or how their car gets shot a couple hundred times, even point blank through the window, they still remain untouched. These have to be the worst actors i've seen in a long time. If you want wooden characters that sound like they are simply reading their lines out loud, look no further. This film came out in 2012, but the cgi looked horrendous, absolutely abysmal. I have to say Jill Valentine is bad ass, she beats the crap out of Alice. Oh, I should also mention Los plagues Rodrigez breaks just about every bone in Leon and that other guy's body, and they act like nothing happened. I mean come on, we see and hear their bones break, get real. Alice also manages to bleed out for an hour and a half straight, without dying. I could go on for another paragraph or two about this movies flaw's, but that would be too much. One more thing, there is an intolerable amount of slow-motion in this film, you know because the movie is so cool we have to see everything in slow-motion, just in case we missed it. And why is Wesker a good guy now? And lastly, what happened to the Redfields? Did they just forget about them or what.This movie is so bad, you will find yourself laughing at how bad it is. If you are willing to stomp reality in the face and let your brain turn to mush, I dare you to watch this film, but please don't spend thirty dollars on it, you'll hate yourself if you do. I say stay away if you want to keep your brain cells, but watch it if you want a good laugh, there are many to be had.!update! I've just noticed that two Re fans came in here and disliked all the negative reviews, some people can't understand the facts and have to cry about it. Well they can enjoy their crappy movie, but I sure won't, thats for darn sure.

Review title: More brain dead than a decapitated zombie
Review_body: I have a theory about Retribution: Writer/director Paul Anderson lost a bet with Uwe Boll and had to make something that combined the absolute worst parts from the entire Resident Evil series of gamesVoice acting as bad as the original. Guns that never, ever need reloading, until the character's plot armour fails. Plot lines that get sold up then go nowhere (Alice's bullet wound). Invisible inventory slots - where exactly was Ada Wong carrying that grapple gun? Intelligent, tool using, team working zombies - the very thing that Umbrella was seeking and failing to create in Extinction.Nothing in it makes a damn bit of sense. How did Alice get from the Arcadia to the facility? What did the Red Queen need her for anyway? What's Jill Valentine being doing since Apocalypse, why has she gone blonde, and when did she get Goddamn superpowers just like everybody else seems to have developed?The movie just expects you to suspend your disbelief, hold all questions to the end (and then forget about them), and just watch some sub-Matrix extended slo-mo fight scenes over and over and over again.All of it I could forgive if at the entire point of the Afterlife / Retribution arc wasn't that Alice was supposed to be de-powered. Well, you could have fooled me. Here she is, flipping and fighting and neck snapping and tearing up armies of zombies and soldiers exactly as before. Anderson the director seemed to have no idea what Anderson the writer was doing.The plus side is that are some great visuals here and Jovovich is as compelling as ever. But that's it. That's the entire draw of the film. There's simply nothing else here to like, and it's so insultingly mindless that I couldn't kick back and enjoy the spectacle.

Now, let's remember that Resident Evil, like a number of other movies, was originally a video game. While never having created a deep and ponderous story-line, a few of the episodes in this series, (let's see now...this is number 5 I think), managed to produce some intriguing action sequences as well as generate interest in the characters. OK, maybe not that much interest, but the flicks weren't too bad as far as these kinds of kill-the-zombies movies go. Our heroine, clad in skin tight black leather suits, always managed a certain charisma, or something like charisma anyway. Needless to say, the series managed sufficient fan support to go all the way to number 5. The Matrix didn't even get to number 4. But in this episode, the entire movie is as about as interesting as watching your dumb kid brother spend an hour and thirty minutes on his video game blasting the zombies on the screen. Maybe watching your kid brother would be more interesting. Maybe the first 30 minutes of the movie really is footage of someone's kid brother blasting zombies in his video game. It might be hard to tell the difference. And, it's all downhill from there. Don't waste your time, even if you are a fan of the series. You will be disappointed.

Review title: My least favorite of the Series
Review_body: I was quite intrigued by the Resident Evil series last year and I was that pumped for them, that I watched the first 4 within one single period. I was so glad to hear that they were making a 5th one, I was dying to see how this next entry would expose more of the series, more mindless zombie action and how they would make more tribute to the games.My first impression of the trailer back in September was that it looked like it could be of some decent promise. I had a feeling the film could still be better than watching the trailer itself.I then see the film, and here's what I thought of it in a few words: confusing, mind-numbing, sometimes out of context and even unethical to plot lines.That's what I mainly though about this film. This 5th installment had so much promise, but instead decided to take things to extreme heights and go in some of the most confusing, most mind-numbing scenes and story lines I have ever seen in a Resident Evil film. Sure, the Resident Evil films partly have twists in their stories over time and all the time, but this one took the bait. It made me as a viewer really confused about where they were taking the story, characters, action and the entire premise of the elements and meaning. Did I mention I was already a tad confused??? I don't expect there to be well-developed things happening in a Resident Evil film, but I do expect there to be some form of entertainment, to say the least. The beginning and most of the first hour is nothing but flashes for what I could see of the 1st and 2nd film, and then there were many different plots happening and jamming in at the same time which made me lost on what was happening.I also found that there were hardly any zombies in this thing. Where were the zombies in this film! They are the prime source to what made this series. I see them and I saw chaos occurring everywhere in the first four films which actually do a good job at creating some form of tension and action. Here there is none of that. And why is it that the character of Leon, who is in the 4th and 6th game installments suddenly thrown into this??? I'll never understand that.In my opinion, I believe they should have just continued the battle on the boat and went from there. It would have created more realism and stay true to the series. This film feels like a differently, filmed entry on it's own.On a positive note, I would say the action sequences and soundtrack score were excellent as always. They were the only elements that kept this film at it's feet (barely).Overall I don't hate this film, but I certainly was disappointed by it. I mean what were the creators thinking when they were throwing scenes around in this film??? And hardly any zombies??? I'd say stick with the first 4, yes even Afterlife. If you think Afterlife is bad (which I really liked a heap), try this and compare them. 5/10

Review title: More boom boom, less blah blah
Review_body: This is basically how I would summarize the fifth installment of the decadent Resident Evil franchise. This is a series of movies that I have yet to fully watch, but at times it seems frustrating to watch good source material poorly used. From some parts that I saw from the original,I think that might be the best. After that I've also seen a bit of Apocalypse, all of Extinction, and have yet to see Afterlife. So far the things I liked about these movies are some of the action, Milla Joviovich in general and for the better part Extinction (Saw it when I was younger). As far as Retribution goes, one shouldn't expect any more than what we get as a standard in Hollywood: All boom boom, no blah blah. On a side note, the ending kind of had me a bit interested, but had this franchise had any sort of impact on me in the last few years, and I would have been pumped. The only reason I don't give this one is because of Milla's physique (Sue me, I'm male) and a generally good set up for the upcoming final movie in the saga.Rating: 3/10

Review title: Please Stop Making "Resident Evil" Movies... You Have Killed The Franchise Long Ago. Please, No More!
Review_body: Yes, after "Apocalypse", it's all been downhill. But this... And I thought that cheesy piece of crap with Ashanti was lame... well, this one gives the term "lame" a whole new meaning. It's downright unwatchable! Yes, MUCH worse than the previous one! You can summarize this in 3 words: lame, confusing, annoying.The whole "plot" (if you can call it that) is as follows: Alice is fighting her way out of an underground Umbrella laboratory with simulated environment -- one minute it's New York, then Hon-Kong, then Siberia, etc. She is being chased by simulated characters that, even though they're not real people (but holograms or something), they still use real ammunition (that never runs out) and are able to hurt a human being.Action is all there is to this movie. Unrealistic, badly-executed, senseless, cheesy, annoyingly predictable excuse for action, that is. No plot whatsoever. In-between, there are some flashbacks (or whatever they're supposed to be) of Alice leading a normal life -- this doesn't fit anywhere into the movie and only confuses the viewer. Then she's (or her clones... it's unclear) running/fighting again, and it goes on and on in a predictably monotonous fashion for the whole duration of the movie. The only redeeming factor, is that we get to see some familiar faces. Rain, Carlos, Jill. But as soon as these characters are introduced, you begin to wish they weren't. One minute they're Alice's friends, the next - they're trying to kill her.Then there's this ANNOYING thing with millions of Alice clones running around (or, in this case, also hanging on clothes hangers or something!). I can't stand that! I hate it when there's more than one Alice! It's a ridiculous concept, and I was hoping that they'd not make the same mistake again, as it was apparent that people hated it, but... that s*** is still happening in this movie, which makes an already unwatchable movie, 10 times worse.You CANNOT understand what's going on at any given point in the movie, and you don't even have any desire to, because this movie is just CRAP from the minute it starts.I fail to understand why anyone would rate this piece of crap higher than 3 stars. This film makes VERY little sense (and I have seen ALL of the Resident Evil movies so far), so, if you watch this movie without having seen any prequels, you're going to think that whoever decided to put this movie out, needs urgent medical attention. Yes, it's THAT bad.This movie is an annoying, stupid, confusing, cheesy, incoherent MESS! I was not disappointed; I was INSULTED!

Review title: Truly Disappointing; one step above direct-t- video
Review_body: I have to admit that I actually enjoy the Resident Evil movies. Despite the mediocre critic reviews, I'm always eager to see the next installments of this highly successful video ...game-to-movie franchise. However I have to admit that in this go-around, even I had a really hard time digesting the nonsense being dished out in this iteration of the series. RE5 fails beyond believe. The storyline is utterly crap. The action are cheesy, the actors are cheesy, the whole movie is a joke to the RE series. I am completely disappointed at how the whole movie turned out. In a nutshell, the film is just a long sequence of fluff and filler whose only goal is to manipulate the audience though a series of scenarios (much like a VIDEO GAME) to get to the next "LEVEL" of the game, or in this case the next movie in production, "Resident Evil 6 – Milking the Audience for DOLLARS!!!"I can't really give you a synopsis of the film, because I'm not even sure what I just watched. All I can say is that it was huge disappointment in every facet possible. Despite the silliness of the previous films they always grounded themselves in some type of realism within the reigns of its remise. This entry doesn't even feel like it's a part of the same franchise. Gone is the fun and it's been replaced with ritzy production values and no discernible storyline. It's a movie based on a video game in which they are actually part of a video game and nothing is really happening.In spite of a somewhat promising start with a cool reverse battle sequence, a "best of franchise" film reel and an inventive and even a little scary trip into suburbia we then move on to the supposed purpose of the film which just doesn't make sense at all. Alice awakes in a high-tech prison cell as a captive of the Umbrella Corporation from the previous films, and it's not long before her buddies come to break her out, characters such as Leon S Kennedy (Urb), Ada Wong (Li) and Luther West (Boris Kodjoe) numbering among them. Alice discovers her former ally Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory) has been mind-controlled by the Umbrella Corp to turn against her, and unravels a conspiracy involving simulated arenas and mass cloning as she fights to preserve whatever's left of the human race.The plot and story were very thin. I had a hard time figuring out what exactly was going on in the story. There were no stakes, no subplot. To sum up the entire movie, Alice gets captures by the Umbrella Corporation and Albert Wesker, decides to send a team in to rescue her even though he's been trying to kill her for the past three movies. In the end, Wesker has now become president; and he's in the process of leading the rest of the US Army on a full-scale final assault against the red queen. In addition, Alice gets "re-enhanced" and has a decision to make weather to stay and stand against the forces of evil or move on. I must say, it is an interesting premise for the next movie in the series (RE 6) even though I feel truly swindled for having to sit through this installment.I cannot recommend seeing this film; it's truly an abomination to the Resident Evil franchise (though highly profitable, with $217 million in the till worldwide to date). RE 4 and RE 5 have made close $500 Million worldwide, and CapCom has already "green-lighted" production for RE 6 and RE 7. So love them or hate them, the Resident Evil motion pictures will be around for some time to come. And even though, I really disliked this film (and I really really DID) it's sad to say, that I AM kind of excited about seeing Resident Evil 6. So call me a SUCKER!!!!! SEE MORE OF MY REVIEWS ON FB @ "THE FARIS REEL"

This film is a departure from the other movies in the series in terms of the filming style and story sequence, its more experimental and unusual, which was refreshing even if not entirely successful. Although the stylism can get out of hand at times, and sometimes seems rather artificial, the movie does accomplish the feeling of being a video game, which is what I think they were going for more in this installment. The action sequences are overall pretty good, if repetitious, and the story line, although simple-minded, is a decent enough backdrop for the theatrical and showy action scenes.While I still think the third movie, Extinction, is the best one by far, this one I liked a lot more than the last one - "Afterlife", which I thought really stank. Nice special effects and visuals, and the 3D was not distracting or annoying, which was welcome (I tend to dislike 3D movies in general)

I'll be honest. My main reason for watching these movies is to see Milla Jovovich in sprayed-on pleather. Why exactly I'm not really sure. She has no prominent female physical characteristics to hook my attention – flat-chested and about as curvaceous as a cocktail stick. But when she dons that garb and springs into action, she's sex on legs.It's never really been enough, but this time it's even less so, and it looks as if the law of ever diminishing returns is starting to bite prominently into this franchise in ways that simply cannot be ignored. This is the equivalent of 96 minutes of watching high-definition video game footage play out before your eyes. Previous entries have at least given some meagre impression of being more...more live action experiences rather than complete exercises in almost total CGI. RETRIBUTION feels like a full stop to all that. It has only the scantest relationship with any real-world constructs and is a cold, calculated and clinical exercise that exists as a visual spectacle with no heart and soul.If there is to be another one, I suspect it will be even less of a film and even more of a machine-tooled computer rendered programme. I might still turn up for the pleather, but even that is beginning to lose its shine and glister. This does not bode well.

Its such a shame the 6 year wait for the final RE movie opening was not about the epic battle as seen in the end of this movie. This movie is made for the adults that loved the cheap 1980s apocalyptic science fiction movies on the rental rows.

Review title: A great addition to the franchise.
Review_body: I will admit this review is a little bias as I am a very big fan of this franchise and there isn't one of these films that I haven't loved, but honestly this fifth installment is indeed a great one. The big thing for me is the shift in direction this movie took, I cant pinpoint what it is but it just feels different to the others, at the beginning we see the usual "My name is Alice" introduction that we've all come to know and love, from then on its a non stop pulse pounding thrill ride that is sure to keep you on your toes. Yes you have to kind of suspend disbelief while watching a Resident Evil movie but that's like most scifi type game stuff, it's not realistic in the least but that's what makes them all so excellent. A lot can be said about Milla, she is the absolute driving force in these films, they wouldn't be as good as they are if someone else were in the role, she never overdoes it and she always kicks ass, however it's good to see a more vulnerable side to her in this installment as she tries to protect a young girl who is her make believe daughter, she's just frakking awesome to put it down to one word. The effects are top notch as usual and as expected, the score is fitting and the colour palette is suited well also, big props for the closing credits song by Bassnectar and Chino Moreno, very cool. Another thing ill mention is the very clever way two characters from previous films were introduced back into the series, Michelle Rodriguez is one tough broad and the Sienna Guillory is cool playing the same character but doing it in an entirely new way.As the film ends we see a set up for the 6th film, and by the looks if it, it's going to be epic. Once it ended I was sitting in the theater just thinking to myself " ooohhhhh wonder what they'll do with that". I cannot wait for the next one, hooray.Fans will love it, non fans will love it, and I hope it gains new fans. Excellent. Probably the best in the series.

Review title: Chix Chat on Film Review: Alice versus Umbrella Corp again.
Review_body: Resident Evil is the next tale of Project Alice (Milla Jovovich) and it picks up at the point where Afterlife left off, with the released passengers afloat on the Arcadia. The opening scenes were very cleverly shot, and this film has some crisp and impressive CGI. I saw it in 3-D so I will admit that I flinched more than once when things came flying off the screen at me or a zombie seemed to get up close and personal. For those who are not particularly familiar with the series, this film gives a complete synopsis of what has transpired in the previous films from the very beginning up to the current circumstances. Anyone looking for a high body count, loads of action and a hodge-podge of nonsense should see this film. The trailer shows that some of the original characters have returned in this installment and I wanted to see how it was done, since I had personally seen the demise of Rain (Michelle Rodriguez) and others in the first film. Then I thought 'duh', if they can have an inventory of Alice then Umbrella Corp can have a bunch of anyone and everyone. One of those nonsense moments that I mentioned was when Rain first shows up on screen and I thought, if you are trying to escape zombies why would you have your windows open? There were so many other WTF moments, but hey it's based on a video game it doesn't have to make sense, says the woman who at a time frequently played Frogger. The fact that this story originated from a video game was oh so obvious this time around. Almost every scene was reminiscent of being in an arcade standing behind your best friend who has mastered the game and continues to survive through to the next level. The problem is that you quickly bore with cheering your friend on a want some action for yourself. Even with all the acrobatic fights, the mutants, the zombies and the big banging explosions, there were moments when I keep thinking 'how much longer'? The climatic fight scene wasn't even that climatic with Alice squaring off against Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory). It was too drawn out for my taste and in the end she did exactly what I was thinking should have been the first defensive move. I am giving this film an amber light, and the only reason it's not a red light is Boris Kodjoe (Luther West).

Here we have the 5th instalment in the Resident Evil series. I was glad to see the writer & director of the first and last film in the franchise was back in his place for the 5th film. I was wrong to hope for such a thing and can only hope now that this be the last Resident Evil film.The film begins with the writer, Paul W.S. Anderson, and his wife, lead actress Milla Jovovich, telling you that you are stupid. Yes, that is right. We, the audience of this new Resident Evil film, are dumb. They assume we are so dumb that we can't remember the events of the last 4 films. In fact, the time spent on explaining what we already know, we might as well have never watched the first 4 films at all.Now I'm not 100% against re-caps or montages that are done in unique ways to remind us of past events, scenes or films. Now I said "done in unique ways." This isn't done in any original new way whatsoever. Instead it is just Milla, as her character Alice, re-telling the story directly to us, the audience. Immediately we are reminded that this is a film, all realism is flushed down the toilet along with any hopes that the Resident Evil film series can maintain any credibility.The film continues to remind us how dumb we must be by using the absolute worse CG effects seen outside of made-for-TV sci-fi movies and children's television shows. 3D or 2D - it does not matter. It is clear to any film enthusiast that this is all shot in front of green screens and the actors/characters are never in any real danger. Therefore pack it up early, even the genius soundtrack masters tomandandy can't save this mess!

Review title: Some nice action sequences but the story line is getting tired
Review_body: In a nutshell Resident Evil:Retribution is like watching a live-action version of the popular RE video games more-so than the other sequels. We have scenes of action and martial arts moves which are the best thing about the movie - Alice kicks ass in very cool scenes of various martial arts moves some done in slo-mo so you can see the moves. Then we have the map scenes which show us where the characters are and the different areas locations just like the map option in the games. We have the boss creatures the executioners, the giant licker and the las plagas type zombies. Unfortunately the story itself is lacking with Alice running around killing things and the other characters just chewing the scenery. The plot if there is one is still the same My Name is Alice and here is a recap of what's happened so far - it doesn't tell us any more that what we already know. She may be the original Alice or may be a clone of herself only that she is the only one who is infected that isn't turned into an evil creature . Returning characters like Rain and Carlos show up as clones with both good and evil versions of their former selves, only that they have memories imprinted on them so they are not the same characters they were in the previous movies. Problem is they are wasted in minor roles and could have been dropped entirely. The story is basically one long video game with getting from point a to point b to finish the game. And of course set it up for the sequel which is an all too familiar formula with horror movies these days. The RE video games revolutionized the video gaming world over the years but the novelty has worn off with so many similar type knockoffs in games and movies that you wonder just how much more they can milk off this franchise. The next sequel which I'm sure there will be one . if they can make 10 or so Friday the 13th movies why not make another RE one. 6/10 - mostly for the slick action scenes and martial arts moves.

I was stunned at how awesomely bad this sequel is. Of its 117 minute running time, it featured maybe 3 minutes of dialogue, and they were badly written. The rest of the film was filled with battle sequences that, while fairly visually impressive, are ridiculously long, tedious and, once it passes the ten minute mark for one battle, very boring. Shoddy script, appalling miscasting of Johann Urb(-a-derp) as Leon, and an extremely weird performance from Li Bingbing as Ada, as it appears they've overdubbed every single one of her lines in post-production. Even given the relatively low expectations of the Resident Evil films, this one is a dud. Awful, awful, awful.

Review title: Casey's Movie Mania: RESIDENT EVIL: RETRIBUTION (2012)
Review_body: All style but no substance is always best characterized Paul W.S. Anderson's directing efforts. In his new movie, RESIDENT EVIL: RETRIBUTION -- the fifth installment in the lucrative series -- continues his similar trend of filmmaking style. Suffice to say, whoever expecting Anderson to learn a thing or two about cohesive structure will be left disappointed.But the movie does show some striking potential -- at least in the first 15 minutes. From the minute one, Anderson dazzles the viewers with an innovative opening credits sequences that runs backwards and in glorious slow-motion, showcasing the explosive attack on the Arcadia by a swarm of missile-launching helicopters. It's certainly an attention-grabbing opener, and Anderson continues to strike gold with the following scene involving Alice's (Milla Jovovich) hallucinatory zombies outbreak in a daylight suburbia. For a while there, Anderson shows some credibility in crafting expertly-staged suspenseful moments rarely seen since his EVENT HORIZON (1997). After a few quiet moments in the Umbrella Corporation where Alice finds herself being held captive and slowly tortured for information by her old friend-turned-brainwashed Jill Valentine (Sienna Guillory), the movie jolts back to vivid life when a system reload allows her to escape (together with a S&M-like skintight suit). She subsequently enters into a simulated Tokyo city at night and gradually being chased by a number of Asian zombies. Again, Anderson makes great use of slow-motion to depict a highly-stylized fight scene. No doubt they are all cool stuff. Of course, if only Anderson continues to maintain that creative momentum for the rest of the movie, RESIDENT EVIL: RETRIBUTION could have been hailed as his most entertaining entry in the series.Unfortunately he loses steam so fast that the subsequent running time is awfully formulaic. From here on, the action -- chase, fistfights, shootouts -- are repetitive and executed in the utmost conventional way possible (Is it because Anderson has exhausted all the budget in the first 15 minutes?).What about the plot? Let's just say Anderson has seemingly thrown away his previous scripts he has wrote for four RESIDENT EVIL movies, jumbled up all of them, and ends up as a patchwork of half-realized ideas. So whoever who are looking for coherent structure to tie back what happen in the previous movies, are best to left their brains at the door and enjoy the mindless ride instead. Oh, wait -- even the word "enjoy the mindless ride" isn't enough to warrant this as a solid B-action picture.As for the cast, they are basically the same old stereotypes. Even the presence of Li Bingbing in her first Hollywood role as Ada Wong is particularly wasted here. Her textbook-like line delivery in English is simply wooden, while Johann Urb's performance as the fan-favorite Leon Kennedy is reduced to a thankless role.Likewise, Anderson concludes the movie with an open ending that seemingly promised for something big will happen (the sixth installment is reportedly will be his last series). Let's just hope the sixth entry in the future will be truly his last in the series.http://caseymoviemania.blogspot.com/

Review title: Finally saw this one, probably one of the better entries...
Review_body: ... at least given this franchise which, for the most part, has been pretty abysmal... This one was one of the more enjoyable films in the series. I liked the concept of the underwater testing area, i liked having the Red Queen back, and i actually really like the hook of Wesker and Alice working together. The real star of the movie, though, was Sienna Guillory's cleavage. Man i never got tired of staring at it. (haha.)I have to admit i liked seeing Barry and Leon in the movie, as well. The strike team idea was neat to revisit, as it always brings me back to the original concept of Resident Evil with the S.T.A.R.S. squad.I haven't been a huge fan of most of the movies in the series, but this one was watchable.

By now we know the drift of these stories - cool outfits - a little girl - cooler guns and gunplay - flying around - lots of butt-kicking. So I'll get to my Best and Worst moments: BEST: at the end when Alice is fighting with Jill - the other bad girl gets ready for battle by injecting herself in the neck with a serum which is going to make her invincible - and there is a big hairy ugly bug in the syringe!!! It must work as she gets shot a couple of dozen times - and she spits the bullets out of her fingertips - pretty cool. I also enjoyed when she was fighting the two (burly) males (good guys) - one of them smashes her directly in the face with a fire extinguisher & she does not even flinch (a bad chick). The worst was the little girl being abducted by the big monster - and then being rescued by Alice - pure cheese - and of the dozens of pods she could have been in, Alice chooses the right one on the first try.Overall I liked it enough, but then, I had low expectations. DonB

For some reason I feel even worse than when I watched the previous film in the theatre. What is going on in this new instalment? First our eyes glance at the screen force feeding our brains with some slow motion reverse shot in the beginning sequence. Then we move to the already mundane "Alice" narrative.Let's move on shall we? Now the next scene in the film shows what we just already seen and totally got the point of, but now the film is moving forward of what was just in reverse in the opening shot. I call this time filler for the weak and pathetic storyline.As we travel through this moronic film, and subsequently figure out that Alice is now once again imprisoned, by Umbrella, and must escape the undergrounds of yet, another compound. Except she learns she has to go through "Holographic" testing arena's, using all the characters from the past as some emotional response from Alice. Wow, I feel like I'm standing on the Star Trek The Next Generation holo-deck and can't find the discontinue program button! Now as Alice moves through the sub-terrain Umbrella facility, we see familiar faces and familiar enemy's some left over from the previous film, including the giant carrying the hammer axe, and once again seeing the same slow motion axe wielding shots. Some of the film scene's included Alice in the earlier times living in suburbia. Well with this scene all I could think of is "Dawn of the Dead" remake, that's all that scene did for me. My apologies go out to the "Dawn of the Dead" remake fans. Yes they stole from that script also.For my final statement I must say this film offers nothing new to the series, it also doesn't offer us anything to think about, there is a lot of time filler scenes, monotonous over dwelling storyline shots, I just can't figure out why they would even make this pathetic film. I don't consider it part of this franchise, I just call it as I see it. That being said, I think it is just an hour and a half rerun. Simply put, don't waste your time. The one star for my rating is for the poor actors/actresses that are a part of this garbage and did what they had to do for a pay check. Now for the film running time. It's says it's about 1 hr 31 mins, but visually it's only about 1 hr 22 mins, the rest of the 9 mins goes to ending credits, I think they put that in slow motion too. What a mess! Not only do we have 9 mins of ending credit's(which is almost unheard of, but a terrible ending indeed). This just proves my original thought that this film was cheaply written and produced, this reminds me of the 80's, what they use to do to slasher films. It's starting all over again. Actually I'd rather watch those cheesy slasher films than this incoherent storyline. I feel like this is the "Frankenstein" of the R/E franchise.The first parts of the franchise takes itself seriously, but this film like I said makes itself look cheaply slapped together in writing, all the while using big budget effects, well sorry to say, visual special effects can't save a storyline, not even in 3D, there is no script here that we haven't seen before, this script makes you feel like taking it to the nearest paper shredder you can find.Note to writers for this film! No more R/E films please, you all suck at writing! I wish I could make a bet with all the idiot money men for this franchise, first of all they have no clue what Resident Evil is, and second I would put my money on all the R/E gaming fans that they could write a stellar script. It would be a million times better than this stinking dirty diaper of a film! Just end this terrible story line that's all I ask of the production company. Stop this madness!Thanks for reading.

Review title: I bet you've seen this before ...
Review_body: Five films in and these things just keep getting better and better and better ... and I'm lying. They are actually almost exactly the same (the only difference is a recurring castmate who might return for every other film to help Alice).Once again Alice (Milla Jovovich - The Fifth Element, Ultraviolet) finds herself in trouble at the hands of the Umbrella Corporation who has (again) developed lethal killing machines/beings/plagues that want to wreak havoc on the remains of humanity (after the first Resident Evil movie over ten years ago). This film is nearly as braindead as the Umbrella-engineered zombies found in the film's first half.The film is so bad that during a zombie attack scene, I asked myself why nobody on the streets fleeing had carried a black umbrella ... they were a multitude of colors with nary a black one in sight. It doesn't matter at all ... but neither does the film.If one wants to continue the tales of Alice, by all means watch this one; but you've seen this before. The entire premise of this fifth film is Alice escaping from a training facility and so every door she enters is simply a new scenario -- that is it. Yawn ... it is always more of the same! No wonder I was so intrigued by black umbrellas.
I don't know what's the point of this chapter, it was like a big video game... Action, action, action and no story whatsoever. Pls skip this one because the.final chapter is awesome!

This franchise has garnered a strong fan-base, yet each addition has had it's critical lashing but been huge at the box office, grossing just short of a billion over it's five feature run making it the most successful video game adaptation. I will always thank one of my mates for getting me into this series, as each addition has been released these zombie slashing movies have gotten better and better, and Retribution is the defining entry, a magnificent adventure. Milla Jovovich is back as the ultimate female action hero in "Resident Evil: Retribution", a brilliant addition to the Zombie-Slaying franchise. Some may think this franchise is running on empty, but I disagree, and this entry features a neat twist added to this instalment which will take you by surprise and keeps things fresh (The film is actually set in artificially controlled environments) Not without it's flaws, there is one moment between Leon and Alice where he tells her not to go after her daughter, it's either the editing here between cuts or the acting, this part felt off key and it's rather cringe, but for every awry line there are plenty of bad-ass lines before and after fights. There are some great stand offs where the characters stare down at each other, there's tension and an element of surprise, getting you ready for the action to explode! And when it does the 3D effects are perfection:- Debris, zombie limbs, gun barrels, bullets and numerous objects soar out the screen at wild speeds, and spectacular depth effects enable the landscape to stretch far into the screen leaving you jaw dropped. Paul W.S Anderson proves yet again that he is the master of 3D immersion, action scenes have never looked so good! Retribution sees Project Alice continue her battle against Umbrella, who have built a giant facility underwater to further test the deadly T-Virus. Using the virus, Umbrella manipulate the world around her and turn people against Alice, most of whom she used to work with, forcing her to up her game in her mission to finish them once and for all. The cloning plot allows Michelle Rodriguez, Colin Salmon and Oded Fehr to reprise their roles, although they don't have much dialogue they still prove they are worthy to make a comeback. For me, this movie has one of the utmost best opening sequences ever, it's like watching 3D action-movie perfection unfold on screen: All edited to go in reverse, Umbrella reign hell on the Arcadia ship, every single camera work is an action shot, it is jaw dropping, beautiful, the definition of epic and masterfully constructed, and Tomandandy's soundtrack plays over it upping the scale of awesome to the top. The Tokyo Corridor of Light fight scene also is one of the best fights I've seen in a movie, the fight choreography is truly spectacular, the editing is swift and cut perfectly making sure continuity flows, which is does perfectly, and the use of 3D here is utterly astounding, in fact a reference quality moment that I'd use to demo my set-up with. Retribution does focus on action more than story, but not at an alarming level, the twists are relatively interesting but obvious yet it pushes the story into exciting territory. Would I watch this again? Already have, at least a dozen times, with near perfect 3D, tough characters, mind-blowing fight sequences, stunning visuals, a rocking soundtrack and a truly epic finale, Retribution is a soaring entry that hits hard and stands tall in the franchise, it's one of those movies you can watch over and over again, unless you rated it rotten.

Review title: No plot, No story but lots of action. Simply a mindless action movie.
Review_body:
Let me put this simply as I can, this is a mindless action movie.
I think Paul W.S. Anderson the director and writer was starting to
run out of ideas and it shows, but I personally liked it because
we had some of the same characters we already knew and I think
it sort of works manly for the action. The action scenes were great, the film makes no sense at all 
mind you, but mostly works because it's action scenes.
Put simply, it's inconsistent in story for whatever reasons, 
I think some people that are fans of these films said there was
more story from what I remember, but it was scrapped because
"Sony" the studio I guess didn't like it, and they wanted it as a mindless
action movie? I think?Anyway, Milla is good as always for this series and I like her sexy
costume that fits well on her sexy shape and makes her look like
an S&M dominatrix which is awesome.
Also it's just fun seeing her kick zombie ass in slow motion,
from what I remember she is in some kind of facility of Umbrella's
and she has to get out for whatever reasons, that's basically the plot.Most may not like it but I did, for me, I'm an action fan and
a fan of this series, it really hit the spot, this one delivers action unlike the others.I give it a 6/10. Not great in story but satisfying in action.
If your a fan of these films give it a look. It's the last decent one.

"Resident Evil: Retribution" is strictly for fans of the series and for those who love mindless, long action sequences filled with blood. Period. Anyone expecting a storyline or strong performances should stay away with this film.The "Resident Evil" series has reached its fifth installment and this latest one delivers the same thing it's good at: mindless action scenes. There is hardly a storyline here. The opening sequence of the film runs way too long. That takes roughly fifteen minutes off the ninety-minute run. It directly takes place where the last film left off and Alice is captured by the Umbrella Corporation once again. Then, with unlikely help from Albert Wesker, she plans to escape the facility (now controlled by the Red Queen, that AI girl) by going through replicas of cities which are used as testing ground for experiments by the Umbrella Corporation. That's it.The replicas explain the numerous environments portrayed in the trailer. Actually, it's only one place. The trailer also displayed the return of some characters that appeared in the previous installments. We see the return of Michelle Rodriguez as Rain Ocampo, Oded Fehr as Carlos Olivera, and some others who died in the previous films. They're actually just clones, made to serve the Umbrella Corporation. However, there are also good clones of them, which are used to be part of the simulations."Retribution" is full of mindless action sequences that never seem to stop. You won't have time to take a breath before the next action sequence begins. The fight choreography is outstanding and the 3D enlivens the scenes. That's probably the shining spot of the whole film.Other than that, the film is decent at best. I wonder if there will be a sequel to this film. Director Paul W. S. Anderson stated that the sixth installment will conclude the series. If that is so, then the last shot of this film sets up a good atmosphere for the next film.Rating: 5/10 Final Verdict: "Resident Evil: Retribution" will attract fans and action buffs but will not be suitable for others who want a clear story and convincing performances.

Since the first movie, non-gamer fans of Resident Evil have come to expect certain things out of the movies. We expect to have halfway decently written characters. We expect elaborate, perhaps unrealistic action sequences that are fun to watch. We expect a little humor. We expect a little bonding and empathy, just enough to make us give a crap about what happens with the characters. We expect a basic plot that isn't too stupid, so we *want* to sit through the movie and find out what happens in the end (also, so we can get a glimpse of what the next movie might be like in the ending scenes).We know the movies aren't perfect. We know that they are based off of a video game. We know that we aren't paying to see Oscar winning performances or realism. We're asking to be entertained, and to see what happens next in the story. That's not asking a lot.But this movie does NOT deliver what fans have come to expect from the series. We expect to see an installment that either competently continues the storyline or provides insight into what we've already seen. That's what the movies have offered all this time. But not this one (and "kind of" doesn't count).This movie is a non-stop action sequence with very little dialog, a bunch of macho posturing, and elements that didn't fit or made no sense. Why make Alice a mother, a "sort of" mother because a child clone just happens to fall in her lap? Why have her magically know sign language to communicate with the child clone? Why have an elaborate fight scene with the Umbrella employee, all for it to end with her grabbing the robot-spider-thingie off her chest? If it was that easy, why not do it in the first place? Alice is anything but blind, and with lightening fast reflexes. Just have her yank the thing off and be done with it.At this point the series should be wrapping up, and with it the plot should be thickened, not diluted. There is absolutely no reason in the world to introduce a simulated environment at this stretch of the ball game. What's the point? To rehash what I've already seen? Useless. To fill in prospective fans when Alice does a predictably dead-pan hash up before EACH AND EVERY GODFORSAKEN MOVIE IN THE SERIES? Useless. The writers missed a golden opportunity to write a good movie, to entice said prospective fans into actually paying money to see the other movies. Instead, they wanted to regurgitate the entire mess, without a Nevada sandstorm.And why introduce previous characters that serve no purpose except to be killed off again? Useless. Why introduce new characters when the movie can't show the audience what they offer to the overall story? Useless. Implying that Alice decides to shrug off her grudge against crew-cut-blonde-in-sunglasses dude just strains credulity in her character map. Useless.I have no reason to believe that fighting the Red Queen is going to be a climax of judgment day, possibly wrapping up the series. Resident Evil: Retribution SHOULD have been the movie to make me believe that by using a real plot with rudimentary written characters. It fails for the reasons above, and then some.I gave this movie a generous 4 out of 10. Not absolute rubbish but getting very close to it. I guess I hold out some shred of hope that all this crap is relevant in the next movie. I'm not holding my breath, though.

Review title: Only a few Redeeming Parts of this Movie...
Review_body: And yes, they involve the women wearing tight-fitting or revealing costumes...That said, there's little else in the film that makes it good. The plot is about as complex as something you'd get out of elementary school. The acting is minimal; Milla Jovovich likes her character, but at this point what else is there to say about Alice? The rest of the cast does an adequate job. The action is almost non-stop, but its all been done before. Even the creatures are all re-treads. The setting is a mishmash between the first and second movies...with a slight, but minor twist. Spoilers:The plot is essentially that Alice has been captured and needs to be saved so she can save humanity...oops, that's not it exactly, but everyone knows that if they have seen the other films in this series. We're told that Alice can help find the weapon. Of course Alice has to fight her way through the maze of the under-ice base (which the Umbrella Corporation took ownership from COBRA after GI JOE defeated them in the first GI JOE movie). Wesker somehow survived, and is now a good guy. He sends a team to save Alice, most of whom end up dying as is usually the case. The big "shocks" of the movie aren't the zombies or the super-creatures, but the appearances of previously-dead characters. As it turns out they are just clones. There's some attempt to make the scenes where they all meet cool, but you just end up not caring. They might as well be masked faceless goons who die by the dozen in every shootout. Speaking of which...it always amazes me how the main characters are impervious to bullets (except when a character needs a convenient wound).The best part of the movie is the last 3 minutes or so when we get the glimpse of the light at the end of the tunnel for this series...though we've been fooled before. This is a series that could have - and should have - been wrapped up about 2 movies ago. I mean think about, the first film set up the world of Resident Evil, the second really displayed the new Alice...the third film should have been Alice being the savior of mankind or something...instead we've had a series of plodding movies that lose all their value after a few minutes of boredom and "been there, done that."This film isn't worth buying or paying money for. Rent it on Netflix or watch it on TV. If it weren't for Sienna Guillory in her tight blue catsuit, Milla Jovovich in her tight black bondage gear, or Li Bingbing in her revealing red dress, nobody would have watched the whole thing...which is why I gave it a 4...for the eye candy.

I've been a long time fan of the Resident Evil series even when people criticized them left and right. I thought they were really entertaining, stylish and inventive. Until now. There is no way I can stick up for this movie or any reason I'd even want to. I can't really give you a synopsis cause I'm not even sure what I just watched. All I can say is that it was huge disappointment in every facet possible. Despite the silliness of the previous films they always grounded themselves in some type of realism within the reigns of its premise. This entry doesn't even feel like it's a part of the same franchise. Gone is the fun and it's been replaced with ritzy production values and no discernible storyline. It's a movie based on a video game in which they are actually part of a video game and nothing is really happening. Despite a somewhat promising start with a cool reverse battle sequence, a best of franchise film reel and an inventive and even a little scary trip into suburbia we than move on to the supposed purpose of the film which just doesn't make sense at all. I mean the choices are just astoundingly bad why make the little girl deaf and the film filled with sign language, why set it in this underground facility, why is all of this happening, with this type of technology how does the remaining human population even have a chance, how is Wesker alive and why is he good now? he's not human??? None of these questions will be answered and lets not even discuss the frustratingly awkward scenes like one in which one of the good guys has a double unnecessary death, an uninspired nod towards the Alien franchise and repetitive scenarios that get less effective the more you see them (really the squid face things). Also, the acting has never been good in the Resident Evil series but Milla Jovovich had evoked a cool sense of fierce heroine, this time around she just seems plain bored as do the other actors. Filled with insipid dialogue, questionable plotting,overlong pacing, a weird bad movie from the 90's score, mediocre fight choreography (except for the scene with the chain) and a crapload of wasted potential this movie just feels like a bad dream. Sometimes, when I'm really looking forward to a movie I'll dream about it the night before and it will be horrible well this is what this feels like. Because in no possible way, what I just watched is a resident evil movie. Despite all of my complaining the movie does have some decent scenes the suburbia one I brought up before was kinda neat, another featuring Ada and Alice against 2 ax men and the chain fight in Tokyo. Besides that it's all just a big plodding waste of existential cinematic trash. A brainless, soulless unintentionally funny horror/action/sci fi hybrid that despite a larger budget,returning cast members and more impressive production values feels like an overlong filler episode that leaves me with a big question mark. Why has this happened to my beloved franchise???

Review title: Much better then the previous installment
Review_body: This is the fifth movie in the Resident Evil series.I was suprised when I saw this as it was much better then the rather dismal fourth film which preceded it.Again we have Alice continuing her fight with Umbrella. There are also returning characters Wesker, Jill, Rain and Carlos from previous films. We are also introduced to new characters from the game such as Leon, Ada and Barry.Sadly the new characters are not much like their video game counterparts. We are also introduced to a young girl Becky.The action scenes are well done and much better then the previous film. Again cloning is still the big topic of the film, and they should have given it a rest. Yeah clones, big deal. Had enough of that rubbish in the previous two films.The movie was really enjoyable to me despite this. They tried to go for a different feel and they mostly succeeded. But don't get too excited at the end of the film. They set it up brilliantly for a massive showdown and sadly they don't do anything with it in the next film. Nothing comes of it.

This movie was fun.Yeah, it was dumb.. stupid.. a lot of it didn't make any sense.Honestly, does anybody go to see a Resident Evil film for logic? to gain insights into the meaning of life?I hope not!This is a Resident Evil film, a sequel, directed by Paul W.S. Anderson.That means.1) Visually beautiful. Personally, I think Paul W.S. Anderson has an incredible eye of cinematography. His films have scenes that are truly breathtakingly beautiful to me.2) Great action!3) Great over-the-top-defying-gravity-n-logic stunts!4) Great creatures and special effects!5) Mila Jovovich in skin tight leather kicking butt!6) Great use of 3D! I personally find Paul's films have some of the best use of this technology.7) A thin veneer of a plot, just enough to string together the action scenes.8) Minimal character depth - just enough to keep you from hating the actors.9) Plot holes that you can drive a mack truck through, and logic that will make your head hurt - if you spend any time really thinking about it.Looking at this list, do you think 'Cool! I want to see it!" or do you focus on #7 through 9 and go "ugh, another dumb big action film."I believe how you answer that question will decide whether or not you will like the film.Me? I loved it. Saw it in 3D IMAX, which I really think helped.7/10 for sheer entertainment value.

Review title: Worst in the series by far
Review_body: This contains some spoilers - though the script is so simple that any spoilers won't ruin it too much anyway.Let's start with the positives - Milla still looks and acts the part of Alice perfectly. But that's the only positive.So onto the film - which starts with pretty much a wasted introduction, a slow motion rewind which eventually plays out properly, and the usual 'My name is Alice' prologue.The rest of the film is essentially a waste of space. Too many 'virtual' worlds that become dull one after the other - they look pretty, but there's never any suspense or even vaguely scary moments.Then there are the characters bought back from the preceding films. This was what I was looking forward to most, but it's a wasted opportunity and they may as well be the undead for all the use they are. Luther was still alive, but just dies in this one for no apparent reason - and no real reason for him being there in the first place.The real kicker though is that Alice is supposed to have no special powers in this film (having lost them previously). Yet you wouldn't realise this by watching the film - okay, she was highly trained by Umbrella - but you wouldn't notice any real difference between non special and special Alice. (She doesn't get reinfected until the end of the film). Yet she takes beating after beating and still carries on almost as normal - that's taking the suspense of belief a little too far.Visually the film is good - great action and sets, but let down by the complete absence of any shade of realism or meaningful dialogue. (I know it's based on a video game, but the previous films at least managed suspense - and showed Alice vulnerable at times).Then you've got the infected in the Moscow zone driving, shooting guns, using chainsaws etc etc................maybe this is an enhancement by the Red Queen, but it's never explained why they can suddenly do everything the humans can.The previous 4 films were each good in their own way - whereas Retribution's likely to be remembered only for the effects. Maybe it was filmed like this for the 3D audience, but in 2D this film sucks.Hopefully RE6 (if it's ever done) will make up for this turkey.

Let's put the obvious fact on the table: It's a new-gen. trash movie, which doesn't deserve any explanation, so I'm going to talk about the differences between RE1 and This.RE1 was a decent zombie-action flick with really dark\horroristic atmosphere, many parts in it are frightening: like having a zombie outbreak "six feet under" which was due to a man's action, even that is scary that people were capable to experiment on such things. And that theme, well, it still gives me the creeps. At least the first RE had merits, but from that point every other part was a downfall throughout the series. RE5 is a typical 3D popcorn movie with it's flashy and yet still lame effects, and poor/static camera views which are due to the intention to see this movie only in 3D. The story has nothing logical saying whatsoever ... the opponents are so cheesy that makes this movie even more 'omega' categorized. Now the positive things for me:-The RE5 theme (you know, the catchy one) was good, at least it has good melody and shows the differences between RE1 scary tone, representing the movie's more intention going on the action-way, if the motion picture is not scary anymore. -The ending had some suspensions (The fighting scenes, and the underwater view was pretty beautiful, some of the pictures here are pretty awesome actually)-The no-name bearded ally marine was pretty funny at his death scene, (he raised his arms, getting shot, lying down, catch his pistole, shoot the mudafu*a, then raises his hands again, and getting shot ... again), That was badass, cheesy, funny at the same time.really bad things:-Russian zombies with weapons ... (Seriously? act 1)-The Alien-like egg scene was so plastic, it made the movie ,again, omega categorized (They could have made it more disgusting with more realistic sticky fluids, and make it more suspenseful, let the actress fight through the eggs-wall with yawning with bloody effects. Seriously? act 2) -I'm not a big RE game fan, but I guess some of the new characters had some connections with the games. For what? It doesn't make it more trustworthy.-The whole story background ... come on, how the hell had we come from the classy virus-zombie-outbreak story to this... actually, I don't get the picture in these previous movies either, but I don't even want to get it. (Seriously? act 3)-They still want to make more sequels ... (Seriously? act 4)That's all I got now, I feel really sorry for Milla Jovovich, I really like her, she's talented in many ways, yet she stars in such craps. P.S.: Did you see how long the credits is? How many people worked on it?... Jesus Christ, the humanity!...

Review title: More explosions, more bodies and more boredom
Review_body: THE fifth installment in the Resident Evil series pummels viewers into submission with its non-stop action.Everywhere you turn, bullets are flying and bombs are exploding. The movie's artificial and glossy look remains, but there is no heartbeat beneath the special effects.The bullet and body counts probably exceed those in The Expendables 2, and readers know what I thought about the latter.Alice (Milla Jovovich) does the same thing that she has done in the four previous flicks. She wears her skintight black outfit and arms herself with all kinds of guns known to man, and then she blows up and kills everything and everyone that stand in her way.You don't need a genius to create a story about her still battling zombies. Just put her in any situation and let her blow her way out her troubles.Alice now finds herself in a huge Umbrella underwater installation that's conducting Godknows how many tests on the virus that caused the zombie permutation in humans. So viewers find sites dedicated to scenarios such as suburbia, New York, Tokyo, Moscow and Berlin.Naturally, our intrepid hero and a Chinese agent in a red slinky dress, Ada Wong (Li Bingbing), must go through all these scenarios with their customary gumption. In the process, they rack up a body count that would make male viewers tremble in their shoes.I presume that Li is starring in her first English movie, because her pronunciation is stilted, but it's certainly better than that of Jay Chou in The Green Hornet (2011).On the way, Alice discovers the virtues of being a mother when she comes upon a cute female child who's in distress, similar to the kid rescued by Ripley in Aliens (1986). What follows is also similar to that in James Cameron's flick, and Alice even goes to the extent of saving the kid caught and placed in a cocoon.** www.jeffleemovies.com (FB and Twitter)

Review title: "Retribution" has actually got some very decent action and 3D effects. The story is still razor-thin.
Review_body: Resident Evil's appeal as a series is almost exclusively rooted in Jovovich's charisma. She combines the enigmatic magnetism of a silent-movie siren with the bravado of an action hero.Anderson is often mistakenly dismissed as a hack but the artist is actually working within the confines of Hollywood genre cinema, constantly transcending and elevating it through the triumph of his avant-Gardie visual sensibility. For those of us who know what we're in for with the series, the fifth instalment is for better or worse, more of the same - albeit with the familiar levels of ridiculousness from its maddeningly inconsistent director/writer .If you liked the other Resident Evil films, you'll like this, and the end suggests there'll be plenty more. A mildly entertaining piece of eye-candy.Paul W.S. Anderson's writing may not have blown minds and our characters may not be up for any awards, but Resident Evil: Retribution showcases tantalising big budget action on a stylistically provocative level.You either enjoy buff female and male characters in tight, form-fitting outfits shooting at zombies and each other, or you don't. It's really that simple. We do not expect quality from Resident Evil any longer. We expect our brains to be expunged of common sense and pumped full of endorphins wearing fetish costumes.The movie is convoluted, of course, but it is also slick, savage and thrilling.

I hate this one, NOT! This is my favorite of all of the Resident Evil movies. Why? How could you not like a movie that has Alice (Milla Yovovich) as a mom in some scenes and dressed in a skin tight leather type outfit? I will never make excuses about appreciating the female form.I didn't like the opening sequence. It was decided to take the attack by Umbrella on the ship Arcadia in backward slow motion. It gave me a headache.
